ground invasion could take place in stages rather than a full-scale invasion, said Daniel Kurtzer, a former U.S. ambassador to Israel. \"Israel is not getting any timetable, it could happen any moment. But it could also happen in stages with additional incursions by small groups of Israeli soldiers rather than a full invasion,\" Kurtzer told CNBC's \"Asia Squawk Box.\" Israel has been amassing troops along the Gaza border in preparation for a ground offensive in a biid to eradicate Hamas militants. On Friday, the Israel Defense Forces issued a 24-hour notice for 1.1 million residents in northern Gaza to evacuate to the south for their own safety. He said Israel is still \"holding its cards very close\" and there could be operational reasons not to go in right away. \"Their bombing and artillery is designed to soften up [the part of] northern Gaza that they may in fact enter,\" said Kurtzer, who is currently a professor at Princeton University. Wang's comments came during a series of calls over the weekend, as world leaders worked to prevent an escalation of the Israel-Hamas war into a broader Middle East crisis. There needs to be a path to a Palestinian state,\" Biden said in an interview filmed Thursday, which aired Sunday evening. The U.S. has historically been one of Israel's biggest allies. But it has also endorsed a two-state solution, which would a separate Palestinian state next to Israel. Read more on Biden's remarks here. — Rebecca Picciotto","publisher":{"@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"CNBC","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/","foundingDate":"1989-04-17","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://sc.cnbcfm.com/applications/cnbc.com/staticcontent/img/cnbc-hdr-logo2.png","width":378,"height":98},"sameAs":["https://www.facebook.com/cnbc","https://www.instagram.com/cnbc","https://www.linkedin.com/company/cnbc","https://twitter.com/cnbc","https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNBC","https://www.youtube.com/cnbc"]},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107309545-1696034653846-gettyimages-1708469685-_m021738_nxrk07cd.jpeg?v=1697401704","width":5864,"height":3909},"thumbnailUrl":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107309545-1696034653846-gettyimages-1708469685-_m021738_nxrk07cd.jpeg?v=1697401704&w=720&h=405"},{"@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Oil prices ease as investors assess impact of Israel-Hamas war","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317545-post","dateModified":"2023-10-15T22:53:20+0000","datePublished":"2023-10-15T22:53:20+0000","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317545-post"},"articleBody":"Oil prices eased in early Asia trade on Monday, reversing last Friday's rally as investors waited to see if the Israel-Hamas conflict draws in other countries, which could drive up prices further and deal a fresh blow to the global economy. Brent futures fell 36 cents, or 0.4%, to $90.53 per barrel and U.S. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude dropped 37 cents, or 0.4%, to $87.32 a barrel by 2215 GMT on Sunday. Both benchmarks rose nearly 6% on Friday, posting their highest daily percentage gains since April, as investors priced in the possibility of a wider Middle East conflict. Brent also recorded a weekly gain of 7.5%, its biggest such increase since February. WTI climbed 5.9% for the week. The conflict in the Middle East has had little impact on global oil and gas supplies, and Israel is not a big producer. But investors and market observers are assessing how the conflict could escalate and what it might mean for supplies from nearby countries in the world's top oil-producing region. — Reuters","publisher":{"@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"CNBC","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/","foundingDate":"1989-04-17","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://sc.cnbcfm.com/applications/cnbc.com/staticcontent/img/cnbc-hdr-logo2.png","width":378,"height":98},"sameAs":["https://www.facebook.com/cnbc","https://www.instagram.com/cnbc","https://www.linkedin.com/company/cnbc","https://twitter.com/cnbc","https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNBC","https://www.youtube.com/cnbc"]},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107275183-1690003700866-gettyimages-51643968-51613615CF012_oil.jpeg?v=1697410400","width":"3000","height":"2010"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107275183-1690003700866-gettyimages-51643968-51613615CF012_oil.jpeg?v=1697410400&w=720&h=405"},{"@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Stock futures edge higher as investors brace for a busy earnings week and new developments in the Middle East","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317543-post","dateModified":"2023-10-15T22:25:27+0000","datePublished":"2023-10-15T22:24:52+0000","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317543-post"},"articleBody":"Stock futures inched higher in overnight trading Sunday as markets faced an uncertain week ahead, with earnings season heating up and developments in the Israel-Hamas war leaving investors wary. Futures tied to the Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.05%, while S & P 500 futures and Nasdaq-100 futures gained 0.07% and 0.17%, respectively. Oil prices s piked more than 5% during Friday's session and posted their best day since April as the conflict between Israel and Hamas fueled some fears related to oil production in the region. Some on Wall Street are bracing for more volatility into year-end as yields and oil prices rise, inflation remains sticky, and conflict ensues in the Middle East, said Eric Johnston, Cantor Fitzgerald's head of equity derivatives and cross-asset. \"This Mideast situation is kind of showing that when you own equities, you are taking risks,\" he told CNBC's \" Closing Bell \" on Friday. \"As a result, you need to have good upside returns in order to justify that risk, because there are things that come out of nowhere, like this situation.\" Over the weekend , Israel's military continued urging residents to evacuate northern Gaza amid a widely anticipated ground invasion. Meanwhile, U.S. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said Sunday that the Senate would work to quickly push through a military aid package to assist Israel as it battles Hamas. Officers found the 32-year-old woman and 6-year-old boy late Saturday morning at a home in an unincorporated area of Plainfield Township, southwest of Chicago, the Will County Sheriff's Office said in a statement on social media. The statement added that the boy was pronounced dead at a hospital and the woman had multiple stab wounds and was expected to survive. An autopsy on the child showed he had also been stabbed multiple times. \"Detectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,\" the sheriff's statement said. According to the sheriff's office, the woman had called 911 to report that her landlord had attacked her with a knife, adding she then ran into a bathroom and continued to fight him off. The boy was stabbed numerous times with a knife, according to an autopsy, the sheriff's office said. The woman had more than a dozen stab wounds and remained hospitalized Sunday and was expected to survive. The Chicago office of the Council on American-Islamic Relations held a news conference later Sunday with a family member and knew their identities. It said text messages exchanged among family members showed the attacker had made disparaging remarks about Muslims. Hamas militants stormed into Israel on Oct. 7 and murdered more than 1,400 Israelis, the vast majority of them civilians. The militants also kidnapped at least 155 people — a number that includes babies and the elderly — and are holding them hostage in Gaza. officials say they've noticed an increase in threatening rhetoric targeting both the Jewish and Muslim communities in the week since the brutal Hamas attacks in Israel. Director Chris Wray said on a call with reporters Sunday that the FBI is moving quickly to mitigate the threats and that the FBI does not discount the possibility that Hamas and other groups could exploit the conflict in the Middle East to call for or plot attacks in the United States. A senior FBI official who spoke on condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the bureau said the majority of the threats that the FBI has responded to were not judged to be credible. But the official said the FBI takes them all seriously nonetheless. The official also said that agents have been encouraged to be \"aggressive\" and proactive in communicating over the last week with faith-based leaders. The official said the purpose of that outreach is not to make anyone feel targeted but rather to ask clerics and others to report to law enforcement anything that seems suspicious. Besides responding to an escalating number of threats, Wray said the FBI was also working through its legal attache office in Tel Aviv to do what it can to locate and identify Americans who remain unaccounted for after last weekend's attacks. — Associated Press","publisher":{"@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"CNBC","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/","foundingDate":"1989-04-17","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://sc.cnbcfm.com/applications/cnbc.com/staticcontent/img/cnbc-hdr-logo2.png","width":378,"height":98},"sameAs":["https://www.facebook.com/cnbc","https://www.instagram.com/cnbc","https://www.linkedin.com/company/cnbc","https://twitter.com/cnbc","https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNBC","https://www.youtube.com/cnbc"]},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107271243-16892685552023-07-12t165406z_1403545678_rc2s12ape9i8_rtrmadp_0_usa-justice-congress.jpeg?v=1697395334","width":"3500","height":"2416"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107271243-16892685552023-07-12t165406z_1403545678_rc2s12ape9i8_rtrmadp_0_usa-justice-congress.jpeg?v=1697395334&w=720&h=405"},{"@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"U.S. State Department says flights out of Israel for Americans will continue Monday and Tuesday","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317516-post","dateModified":"2023-10-15T17:55:33+0000","datePublished":"2023-10-15T17:55:33+0000","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317516-post"},"articleBody":"The U.S. Department of State on Sunday announced that the charter flights out of Israel offered to American citizens will continue \"on a rolling basis\" on Monday and Tuesday. The State Department set up the flights for U.S. citizens stranded in Israel, unable to leave due to the limited availability of commercial flights out of the country. \"We urge those wishing to leave to take advantage of these charters while they are available,\" the department said in a statement. Only U.S. citizens are eligible for the flights and must sign an agreement prior to departure that pledges to repay the U.S. government for the travel. The flights will leave from Israel's Ben Gurion International Airport. The department also provided details on how U.S. citizens in the Israeli city of Haifa can leave via a 10- to 12-hour ship ride to Cyprus on Monday. Those wishing to take the ship must arrive at Haifa port passenger terminal at 9 a.m. local time on Monday. The U.S. government is still negotiating how to get American citizens in Gaza out of the region. It had secured a route of safe passage via the Rafah gate border crossing from Gaza to Egypt, but Americans trying to flee reportedly still have not been let through. In the meantime, the government is encouraging Americans in Gaza to fill out a crisis intake form in case they need to be contacted on short notice. We must provide Israel with the support required to defend itself,\" Schumer said on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter. Schumer, the highest-ranking Jewish elected official in the United States, took the trip to show support for Israel ahead of an expected request from President Joe Biden for Congress to approve wartime funding for Israel as well as Ukraine. Schumer, a Democrat, has said he would also hold discussions with Israeli officials what kind of support the country would need for both military and humanitarian operations. Republican Sens. The official IRNA news agency said Ebrahim Raisi and Emmanuel Macron spoke over the phone. The Iranian president made no mention of the unprecedented Oct. 7 incursion by Gaza's militant Hamas group into southern Israel that sparked the latest Hamas-Israel war. Iran has long been a supporter of Hamas. \"The situation will be complicated ... if the crimes by the Zionist regime, including the killing of people and blockade of Gaza, are not stopped,\" Raisi was quoted as saying, referring to Israel. IRNA did not provide further details. Earlier, the Elysee Palace confirmed this weekend that Macron planned to talk to Raisi to urge Iran not to fuel tensions in the region or provide any operational support to Hamas. Macron intended to press the argument that bringing the violence to a rapid end is in everyone's interests, including Iran's, the presidential office said. France feels that Iran can play a positive role in the crisis by simply not getting involved in it, either with \"words that are unacceptable\" or by supporting Hamas. Over the weekend, Raisi also spoke with leaders of Arab nations of Iraq, Oman and Qatar and urged them to support Gaza's Palestinians, Iranian media said. It was the last of Blinken's meetings with Arab leaders amid increasing fears that an impending Israeli ground offensive into Gaza could spark a wider war with devastating humanitarian consequences. Francis on Sunday renewed his call for the release of Israeli hostages held by Gaza's militant Hamas rulers and called for humanitarian corridors to help those under siege in Gaza. \"I continue to follow with much sorrow what is happening in Israel and Palestine,\" Francis said during his Sunday's Angelus prayer in St. Peter's Square. \"I think back to the many people, especially the little ones and the elderly.\" The Pope reiterated his appeal for the release of scores of Israeli hostages snatched during Hamas' deadly incursion into southern Israel last weekend and taken to Gaza. \"I strongly ask that the children, the elderly, women and all civilians don't become victims of the conflict,\" Francis said. Waving Palestinian flags, the rally also marked a major showing for the banned Islamist movement Al Adl Wa Ihssane, which supports Hamas. After Hamas's unprecedented and deadly Oct. 7 incursion into Israel, Morocco issued a statement condemning the violence. Royal Air Maroc, temporarily cancelled flights from Casablanca to Tel Aviv — a route that began in 2021. Demonstrators marched in central Rabat and threw smoke bombs and fireworks as riot police stood between them and the Parliament building and other landmarks. Hassan Ait Amar, a 52-year-old from Casablanca, carried a sign demanding Morocco's lawmakers revoke a normalization of ties with Israel. \"If they want peace, they (Israel) should respect Palestinians, international law and a two-state solution,\" he said. Israel and Morocco normalized relations as part of the 2020 Abraham Accords, a series of diplomatic agreements between Israel and four Arab countries brokered by then-President Donald Trump. Israel is home to a large community of Jews of Moroccan descent. The UNRWA warned that despite Israel's order to evacuate the north, many people will not be able to flee, particularly pregnant women, children, the elderly, and people with disabilities. \"UNRWA shelters in Gaza and northern Gaza are no longer safe. This is unprecedented,\" it said. \"This war should be no exception, protection of civilians and civilian infrastructure, including United Nations buildings, applies to this conflict too.\" Israel has ordered roughly 1 million residents in northern Gaza to evacuate to the south ahead of an anticipated ground offensive. Separately, the UNRWA warned that 2 million people are at risk as water runs out in Gaza and called for humanitarian supplies to be let in. It said its newly relocated base in the south is also running out of water as it takes in refugees, thousands of whom it said followed the evacuation order. UNRWA Commissioner-General Philippe Lazzarini said fuel needs to be brought in immediately to guarantee safe drinking water. \"If not, people will start dying of severe dehydration, among them young children, the elderly and women. Water is now the last remaining lifeline. I appeal for the siege on humanitarian assistance to be lifted now,\" he said. — Christine Wang","publisher":{"@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"CNBC","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/","foundingDate":"1989-04-17","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://sc.cnbcfm.com/applications/cnbc.com/staticcontent/img/cnbc-hdr-logo2.png","width":378,"height":98},"sameAs":["https://www.facebook.com/cnbc","https://www.instagram.com/cnbc","https://www.linkedin.com/company/cnbc","https://twitter.com/cnbc","https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNBC","https://www.youtube.com/cnbc"]},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107317471-1697362856583-gettyimages-1723112923-AFP_33YA3MT.jpeg?v=1697362917","width":"4176","height":"2784"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107317471-1697362856583-gettyimages-1723112923-AFP_33YA3MT.jpeg?v=1697362917&w=720&h=405"},{"@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"IDF renews calls for residents to evacuate to southern Gaza","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317447-post","dateModified":"2023-10-15T09:40:02+0000","datePublished":"2023-10-15T03:21:45+0000","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317447-post"},"articleBody":"The Israel Defense Forces reiterated its call for residents to evacuate to southern Gaza, in a post on X , the social media platform formerly known as Twitter. Earlier, the military posted another video listing other acts committed by Hamas, saying the Palestinian militant group \"has shown the world time and time again what they are capable of.\" \"Now the IDF is prepared to counter with an even greater force. There is no place in the world for terrorism,\" it said. The posts come as Israel is expected to commence a ground offensive in Gaza. — Christine Wang","publisher":{"@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"CNBC","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/","foundingDate":"1989-04-17","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://sc.cnbcfm.com/applications/cnbc.com/staticcontent/img/cnbc-hdr-logo2.png","width":378,"height":98},"sameAs":["https://www.facebook.com/cnbc","https://www.instagram.com/cnbc","https://www.linkedin.com/company/cnbc","https://twitter.com/cnbc","https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNBC","https://www.youtube.com/cnbc"]},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107317340-1697283640269-gettyimages-1722796924-AFP_33Y64F4.jpeg?v=1697362802","width":"7324","height":"4458"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107317340-1697283640269-gettyimages-1722796924-AFP_33Y64F4.jpeg?v=1697362802&w=720&h=405"},{"@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Israel Defense Forces says its preparing for 'wide range' offensive","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317408-post","dateModified":"2023-10-14T17:56:04+0000","datePublished":"2023-10-14T17:27:59+0000","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317408-post"},"articleBody":"The Israel Defense Forces, or IDF, said it was \"preparing to implement a wide range of offensive operative plans\" which will include \"an integrated and coordinated attack from the air, sea and land\" against Hamas. The IDF added that it had already completed its mobilization of hundreds of thousands of servicemen for the counteroffensive, according to a statement translated by NBC News . \"IDF battalions and soldiers are deployed all over the country and are prepared to increase readiness for the next stages of the war — with an emphasis on a significant ground operation,\" the statement added. — Amanda Macias","publisher":{"@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"CNBC","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/","foundingDate":"1989-04-17","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://sc.cnbcfm.com/applications/cnbc.com/staticcontent/img/cnbc-hdr-logo2.png","width":378,"height":98},"sameAs":["https://www.facebook.com/cnbc","https://www.instagram.com/cnbc","https://www.linkedin.com/company/cnbc","https://twitter.com/cnbc","https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNBC","https://www.youtube.com/cnbc"]},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107317334-1697283085370-gettyimages-1723190578-AA_14102023_1376053.jpeg?v=1697305828","width":"5040","height":"3360"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107317334-1697283085370-gettyimages-1723190578-AA_14102023_1376053.jpeg?v=1697305828&w=720&h=405"},{"@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Deal to allow Americans out of Gaza through Rafah gate faces obstacles, officials say","url":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317446-post","dateModified":"2023-10-15T07:13:20+0000","datePublished":"2023-10-15T03:06:54+0000","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html#107317446-post"},"articleBody":"The tentative agreement to grant Americans in Gaza safe passage into Egypt through the Rafah gate continues to face significant obstacles to implementation, U.S. officials told NBC News . Previous discussions between Egypt, the U.S., Qatar and Israel looked set to allow Americans across the border crossing during a five-hour window Saturday, but NBC reports the deadline came and went without any immediate sign of success. One official told NBC the parties are continuing to negotiate. Secretary of State Antony Blinken is expected to land in Cairo on Sunday and the deal is set to be a key issue on his agenda. While sticking points remain, the State Department has urged the estimated 500 to 600 Americans in Gaza to move south, warning that if the crossing opens, the window could be brief. — NBC News, Christine class="PageBuilder-col-full PageBuilder-col PageBuilder-article"><div class="TopBanner-container" data-top-banner-placeholder="true"><script>
          (function() {
            const userMembershipOnLastVisit = localStorage.getItem("cnbcMeta__cachedUserMembership");
            if (!userMembershipOnLastVisit) {
              // If no user membership is stored, user is likely not logged in.
              // These users will typically see the banner.
              return;
            }

            const { isPro, isInvestingClubUser } = JSON.parse(userMembershipOnLastVisit);
            if (!(isPro || isInvestingClubUser)) {

              return;

        </script></div></div></div><div class="PageBuilder-containerWidth100 PageBuilder-pageRow"><div class="PageBuilder-col-full PageBuilder-col PageBuilder-article"><div><header class="LiveBlogHeader-articleHeader" id="main-article-header"><div class="LiveBlogHeader-headerContentContainer"><div class="LiveBlogHeader-wrapperHeroNoImage LiveBlogHeader-wrapperHero LiveBlogHeader-wrapper LiveBlogHeader-wrapperNoImage"><div class="LiveBlogHeader-liveUpdatesPill"><p>LIVE UPDATES</p></div><div class="LiveBlogHeader-timestampAndShareBarContainer"><div class="LiveBlogHeader-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">Updated Sun, Oct 15 2023<span class="LiveBlogHeader-datetimeDivider"></span>11:25 PM EDT</time></div><div class="SocialShare-socialShare" data-test="SocialShare" id="social-buttons-transporter"><span class="SocialShare-socialShareText">Share</span><button class="SocialShare-socialShareButton" data-test-allaccess="false" data-test-pro="false" data-test-ic="false"><span aria-hidden="true" class="SocialShare-socialShareFacebook" data-analytic-id="Share Published" data-location="Article Header" data-provider="facebook"></span><span class="SocialShare-socialShareLabel">Share Article via Facebook</span></button><button class="SocialShare-socialShareButton" data-test-allaccess="false" data-provider="twitter"></span><span class="SocialShare-socialShareLabel">Share Article via Twitter</span></button><button class="SocialShare-socialShareButton" data-test-allaccess="false" data-test-pro="false" data-test-ic="false"><span aria-hidden="true" class="SocialShare-socialShareLinkedin" data-analytic-id="Share Published" data-location="Article Header" data-provider="linkedin"></span><span class="SocialShare-socialShareLabel">Share Article via LinkedIn</span></button><button class="SocialShare-socialShareButton" data-test-allaccess="false" data-test-pro="false" data-test-ic="false"><span aria-hidden="true" class="SocialShare-socialShareEmail" data-analytic-id="Share Published" data-location="Article Header" data-provider="email"></span><span class="SocialShare-socialShareLabel">Share Article via Email</span></button></div></div><h1 class="LiveBlogHeader-headline">Israel-Hamas war live updates: Iran warns war could expand; China says Gaza offensive is &#x27;beyond self-defense&#x27;</h1><div class="LiveBlogHeader-authorContainer"><div class="LiveBlogHeader-author"><div class="Author-author"><div class="Author-authorInfo"><div class="Author-authorNameAndSocial"><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/rebecca-picciotto/" class="Author-authorName">Rebecca Picciotto<span class="Author-authorUnderline"></span></a></div></div></div></div><div class="LiveBlogHeader-author"><div class="LiveBlogHeader-authorDivider"></div><div class="Author-author"><div class="Author-authorInfo"><div class="Author-authorNameAndSocial"><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/annie-nova/" class="Author-authorName">Annie Nova<span class="Author-authorUnderline"></span></a></div></div></div></div><div class="LiveBlogHeader-author"><div class="LiveBlogHeader-authorDivider"></div><div class="Author-author"><div class="Author-authorInfo"><div class="Author-authorNameAndSocial"><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/sam-meredith/" class="Author-authorName">Sam Meredith<span class="Author-authorUnderline"></span></a></div></div></div></div><div class="LiveBlogHeader-author"><div class="LiveBlogHeader-authorDivider"></div><div class="Author-author"><div class="Author-authorInfo"><div class="Author-authorNameAndSocial"><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/christine-wang/" class="Author-authorName">Christine Wang<span class="Author-authorUnderline"></span></a></div></div></div></div></div><div class="LiveBlogHeader-explainer"><div class="group"><p><em>This is CNBC&#x27;s live blog tracking developments on the Israel-Hamas war. See below for the latest updates.</em></p></div></div></div></div></header></div></div></div><div class="PageBuilder-containerFluidWidths PageBuilder-pageRow"><div class="PageBuilder-col-9 PageBuilder-col PageBuilder-article"><div class="FeaturedContent-articleBody" id="LiveBlogArticle-featuredContent-3" data-module="featuredContent" data-test="featuredContent-0" data-analytics="LiveBlogArticle-featuredContent-3-0"><span class="HighlightShare-hidden" style="top:0;left:0"></span><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317476" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Traffic is stopped as Israeli armoured vehicles advance toward the border with the Gaza Strip on October 15, 2023, amid the ongoing battles between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Menahem Kahana | Afp | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>Israel&#x27;s military continued to urge residents to move from northern Gaza to the south as it pledged to counter Hamas with &quot;an even greater force.&quot; The Israel Defense Forces said it would not carry out any military operations along the evacuation route from 10 a.m. local time (3 a.m. ET) to 1 p.m. Sunday.</p><p>The evacuation orders have been criticized by many humanitarian agencies, however. After negotiations between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and U.S. President Joe Biden, a decision to renew water supplies to parts of southern Gaza was agreed upon, Israel Energy Minister Israel Katz said on Sunday. The UN warned late Saturday that the lack of water and fuel in Gaza had &quot;become a matter of life or death.&quot;</p><p>Energy Minister Israel Katz said that the decision to partially renew water supplies was in line with Israeli policy, which is to tighten a blockade on the Hamas-ruled territory.</p><p>Meanwhile, U.S. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said on Sunday that the Senate would swiftly push through a military aid package to help Israel in its fight against Hamas.</p><p>&quot;We will work to move this aid through the senate ASAP, and the Israeli leaders made it clear to us they need the aid quickly,&quot; said Schumer during a trip to Israel.</p><p>Separately, the U.S. Embassy in Israel <a href="https://il.usembassy.gov/security-alert-10/" target="_blank">said</a> it would help Americans and their immediate family members to depart the northern Israeli port city of Haifa via sea to Cyprus on Monday. &quot;Boarding will proceed in order of arrival and is on a space-limited basis,&quot; the embassy said.</p></div><div role="region" aria-labelledby="Placeholder-ArticleBody-Video-107317098"><div role="button" tabindex="0" id="Placeholder-ArticleBody-Video-107317098" class="PlaceHolder-smallMarginTop PlaceHolder-wrapper" data-vilynx-id="7000319003" data-test="VideoPlaceHolder"><div class="InlineVideo-videoEmbed" id="InlineVideo-0" data-test="InlineVideo"><div class="InlineVideo-wrapper"><div class="InlineVideo-inlineThumbnailContainer"><img class="InlineVideo-videoThumbnail" src="https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/107316896-1697207001653-gettyimages-1721878555-AFP_33Y423G.jpeg?v=1697221817&amp;w=750&amp;h=422&amp;vtcrop=y" alt="Civilians scramble to flee north Gaza ahead of expected Israeli ground offensive"/><span class="InlineVideo-videoButton"></span><span><div class="undefined PlayButton-container" data-test="PlayButton"><div class="PlayButton-featured PlayButton-base" data-type="play"><span class="PlayButton-flyout">watch now</span><span class="icon-play-triangle PlayButton-icon"></span></div></div></span></div><div class="InlineVideo-videoFooter"><div class="InlineVideo-videoDurationContainer"><span class="InlineVideo-videoLabel">VIDEO</span><span class="InlineVideo-videoDurationWithLeading0">1:03</span><span class="InlineVideo-videoDuration InlineVideo-videoLabel">01:03</span></div><div class="InlineVideo-title">Civilians scramble to flee north Gaza ahead of expected Israeli ground offensive</div><div class="InlineVideo-section"><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/news-videos/">News Videos</a></div></div></div></div><div class="PlaceHolder-endCard PlaceHolder-inactive "></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken will head back to Israel after meeting with Saudi Arabia&#x27;s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on Sunday. The top U.S. diplomat is also expected to land in Egypt later in the day and work on a deal to grant safe passage of Americans currently in Gaza through the Rafah gate — the only crossing between Egypt and the Gaza Strip.</p><p>Gaza — a narrow strip of land sandwiched between Egypt, Israel and the Mediterranean Sea — has been pounded by Israeli forces in response to Hamas&#x27; brutal attack on Israel last weekend. The death toll continues to tick higher, with at least 1,300 killed in Israel and 2,300 in Gaza.</p></div><div class="group"><div class="RelatedContent-relatedContent" id="LiveBlogArticle-RelatedContent-1"><div class="RelatedContent-container"><div class="RelatedContent-nonCollapsibleContent"><h2 class="RelatedContent-header">More CNBC coverage of the Israel-Hamas war</h2><div class="group"><ul><li><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html">Israel-Hamas war live updates: U.S. offers sea evacuation to Americans in Israel</a></li><li><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/14/israel-hamas-gaza-live-updates.html">Shelling continues in Gaza; Israel prepares for next stage of operations</a></li><li><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/13/hezbollah-joining-conflict-in-neighboring-israel-would-be-a-gamechanger.html">Iran-backed Hezbollah joining Israel-Hamas conflict would be a &#x27;game changer,&#x27; expert says</a></li><li><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/13/civilians-trapped-in-gaza-cant-escape-israels-siege.html">&#x27;There is nowhere to hide from the bombs&#x27;: Civilians trapped in Gaza can&#x27;t escape Israel&#x27;s siege</a></li><li><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/10/hamas-israel-conflict-heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-hamas.html">What is Hamas? What you need to know about the militant group that rules the Gaza Strip</a></li><li><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/12/israel-hamas-war-the-iron-dome-missile-defense-system-explained.html">What is Israel&#x27;s Iron Dome? Here&#x27;s what you need to know about the missile defense system</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="LiveBlogBody-articleBody" id="LiveBlogArticle-LiveBlogBody-4" data-module="LiveBlogBody" data-test="liveBlogBody-1" data-analytics="LiveBlogArticle-liveBlogBody-4-1"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-blogTopBorder"></div><span class="HighlightShare-hidden" style="top:0;left:0"></span><div class="LiveBlogBody-postContainer"><div class="LiveBlogBody-pillStickyPosition"><div class="LiveBlogBody-pillVerticalOffset"></div></div><div id="107317566-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="LiveBlogBody-firstPostAnchor"></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">8 Min Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Israel&#x27;s ground offensive may &#x27;happen in stages&#x27; rather than a full invasion, says former ambassador</h2><div class="group"><p>Israel&#x27;s ground invasion could take place in stages rather than a full-scale invasion, said Daniel Kurtzer, a former U.S. ambassador to Israel.</p><p>&quot;Israel is not getting any timetable, it could happen any moment. But it could also happen in stages with additional incursions by small groups of Israeli soldiers rather than a full invasion,&quot; Kurtzer told CNBC&#x27;s &quot;Asia Squawk Box.&quot;</p><p>Israel has been amassing troops along the Gaza border in preparation for <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/13/israel-hamas-gaza-live-updates.html">a ground offensive</a> in a biid to eradicate Hamas militants. On Friday, the Israel Defense Forces issued a 24-hour notice for 1.1 million residents in northern Gaza to evacuate to the south for their own safety.</p><p>He said Israel is still &quot;holding its cards very close&quot; and there could be operational reasons not to go in right away.</p><p>&quot;Their bombing and artillery is designed to soften up [the part of] northern Gaza that they may in fact enter,&quot; said Kurtzer, who is currently a professor at Princeton University. He added there&#x27;s also a psychological aspect keeping Hamas on its toes and ensuring that Israel will have some &quot;operational surprise.&quot;</p><p><em>— Lee Ying Shan</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div><div id="107317562-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">36 Min Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">China says Israel&#x27;s actions have &#x27;gone beyond self defense&#x27; in Gaza</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317564" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Internally displaced Palestinians take refuge in a United Nations school, in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza Strip on October 15, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Nurphoto | Nurphoto | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>China urged Israel to heed calls from the international community to end its collective punishment of Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.</p><p>&quot;Israel&#x27;s actions have gone beyond self-defense and it should heed the call of the international community and the Secretary-General of the United Nations to stop its collective punishment of the people in Gaza,&quot; China Foreign Minister Wang Yi <a href="https://english.news.cn/20231015/fbceeb84a1e5401283c127ac9425dd50/c.html" target="_blank">reportedly told</a> his Saudi Arabia counterpart Faisal bin Farhan Al Saud <a href="https://www.fmprc.gov.cn/wjbzhd/202310/t20231015_11161058.shtml" target="_blank">in a call</a> on Sunday.</p><p>Wang&#x27;s comments came during a series of calls over the weekend, as world leaders worked to prevent an escalation of the Israel-Hamas war into a broader Middle East crisis.</p><p><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/16/china-says-israels-actions-in-gaza-have-gone-beyond-self-defense.html">Read more here</a>.</p><p><em>— Clement Tan</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317565-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">2 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Biden says &#x27;there needs to be a path to a Palestinian state&#x27;</h2><div class="group"><p>U.S. President Joe Biden said in an interview on CBS&#x27; &quot;<a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/president-joe-biden-2023-60-minutes-transcript/" target="_blank">60 Minutes</a>&quot; that he believes Hamas must be fully eliminated and that it is necessary to establish a Palestinian state.</p><p>&quot;There needs to be a Palestinian Authority. There needs to be a path to a Palestinian state,&quot; Biden said in an interview filmed Thursday, which aired Sunday evening.</p><p>The U.S. has historically been one of Israel&#x27;s biggest allies. But it has also endorsed a two-state solution, which would a separate Palestinian state next to Israel.</p><p><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/16/biden-there-must-be-a-path-to-a-palestinian-state.html">Read more on Biden&#x27;s remarks here.</a></p><p><em>— Rebecca Picciotto</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317545-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">5 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Oil prices ease as investors assess impact of Israel-Hamas war</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107275183" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Oil prices are expected to increase in the second half of 2023, according to the International Energy Forum.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Christopher Furlong | Getty Images News | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>Oil prices eased in early Asia trade on Monday, reversing last Friday&#x27;s rally as investors waited to see if the Israel-Hamas conflict draws in other countries, which could drive up prices further and deal a fresh blow to the global economy.</p><p>Brent futures fell 36 cents, or 0.4%, to $90.53 per barrel and U.S. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude dropped 37 cents, or 0.4%, to $87.32 a barrel by 2215 GMT on Sunday.</p><p>Both benchmarks rose nearly 6% on Friday, posting their highest daily percentage gains since April, as investors priced in the possibility of a wider Middle East conflict.</p><p>Brent also recorded a weekly gain of 7.5%, its biggest such increase since February. WTI climbed 5.9% for the week.</p><p>The conflict in the Middle East has had little impact on global oil and gas supplies, and Israel is not a big producer.</p><p>But investors and market observers are assessing how the conflict could escalate and what it might mean for supplies from nearby countries in the world&#x27;s top oil-producing region.</p><p>— <em>Reuters</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317543-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">5 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Stock futures edge higher as investors brace for a busy earnings week and new developments in the Middle East</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107308363" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, September 28, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Brendan McDermid | Reuters</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/stock-futures-today-live-updates.html">Stock futures inched higher</a> in overnight trading Sunday as markets faced an uncertain week ahead, with earnings season heating up and developments in the Israel-Hamas war leaving investors wary.</p><p>Futures tied to the <span class="QuoteInBody-quoteNameContainer" data-test="QuoteInBody" id="LiveBlogArticle-QuoteInBody-undefined"><a href="/quotes/@DJ.1/">Dow Jones Industrial Average</a><span class="QuoteInBody-inlineButton"><span class="AddToWatchlistButton-watchlistContainer" id="-WatchlistDropdown" data-analytics-id="-WatchlistDropdown"><button class="AddToWatchlistButton-watchlistButton" aria-label="Add To Watchlist" data-testid="dropdown-btn"><span class="AddToWatchlistButton-addWatchListFromTag"></span></button></span></span></span> added 0.05%, while <span class="QuoteInBody-quoteNameContainer" data-test="QuoteInBody" id="LiveBlogArticle-QuoteInBody-undefined"><a href="/quotes/@SP.1/">S&amp;P 500</a><span class="QuoteInBody-inlineButton"><span class="AddToWatchlistButton-watchlistContainer" id="-WatchlistDropdown" data-analytics-id="-WatchlistDropdown"><button class="AddToWatchlistButton-watchlistButton" aria-label="Add To Watchlist" data-testid="dropdown-btn"><span class="AddToWatchlistButton-addWatchListFromTag"></span></button></span></span></span> futures and <span class="QuoteInBody-quoteNameContainer" data-test="QuoteInBody" id="LiveBlogArticle-QuoteInBody-undefined"><a href="/quotes/@ND.1/">Nasdaq-100 futures</a><span class="QuoteInBody-inlineButton"><span class="AddToWatchlistButton-watchlistContainer" id="-WatchlistDropdown" data-analytics-id="-WatchlistDropdown"><button class="AddToWatchlistButton-watchlistButton" aria-label="Add To Watchlist" data-testid="dropdown-btn"><span class="AddToWatchlistButton-addWatchListFromTag"></span></button></span></span></span> gained 0.07% and 0.17%, respectively.</p><p>Oil prices s<a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/13/oil-prices-crude-futures-rise-after-us-tightens-sanctions-on-russia.html">piked more than 5%</a> during Friday&#x27;s session and posted their best day since April as the conflict between Israel and Hamas fueled some fears related to oil production in the region.</p><p>Some on Wall Street are bracing for more volatility into year-end as yields and oil prices rise, inflation remains sticky, and conflict ensues in the Middle East, said Eric Johnston, Cantor Fitzgerald&#x27;s head of equity derivatives and cross-asset.</p><p>&quot;This Mideast situation is kind of showing that when you own equities, you are taking risks,&quot; he told CNBC&#x27;s &quot;<a href="https://www.cnbc.com/closing-bell/">Closing Bell</a>&quot; on Friday. &quot;As a result, you need to have good upside returns in order to justify that risk, because there are things that come out of nowhere, like this situation.&quot;</p><p><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-and-latest-and-news-on-gaza.html">Over the weekend</a>, Israel&#x27;s military continued urging residents to evacuate northern Gaza amid a widely anticipated ground invasion. Meanwhile, U.S. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said Sunday that the Senate would work to quickly push through a military aid package to assist Israel as it battles Hamas.</p><p><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/15/stock-futures-today-live-updates.html">See CNBC&#x27;s live blog for complete markets coverage.</a></p><p>— <em>Samantha Subin</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317542-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">5 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Man killed Muslim boy and wounded woman in hate crime motivated by Israeli-Hamas war, police say</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107312412" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption"></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Rose Abuin | New York Daily News | Tribune News Service | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>A 71-year-old Illinois man was charged Sunday with a hate crime, accused of fatally stabbing a young boy and seriously wounding a woman because of their Islamic faith and the Israel-Hamas war, authorities said.</p><p>Officers found the 32-year-old woman and 6-year-old boy late Saturday morning at a home in an unincorporated area of Plainfield Township, southwest of Chicago, the Will County Sheriff&#x27;s Office said in a statement on social media.</p><p>The statement added that the boy was pronounced dead at a hospital and the woman had multiple stab wounds and was expected to survive. An autopsy on the child showed he had also been stabbed multiple times.</p><p>&quot;Detectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,&quot; the sheriff&#x27;s statement said.</p><p>According to the sheriff&#x27;s office, the woman had called 911 to report that her landlord had attacked her with a knife, adding she then ran into a bathroom and continued to fight him off.</p><p>The boy was stabbed numerous times with a knife, according to an autopsy, the sheriff&#x27;s office said. The woman had more than a dozen stab wounds and remained hospitalized Sunday and was expected to survive.</p><p>The Chicago office of the Council on American-Islamic Relations held a news conference later Sunday with a family member and knew their identities. It said text messages exchanged among family members showed the attacker had made disparaging remarks about Muslims.</p><p>The Muslim civil liberties organization called the crime &quot;our worst nightmare,&quot; and part of a disturbing spike in hate calls and emails since the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war.</p><p>— <em>Associated Press</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317539-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">5 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">U.S. State Department says 30 Americans killed in Israel, 13 are still missing</h2><div class="group"><p>The U.S. State Department says the number of Americans killed since the outbreak of war between Israel and Hamas has risen to 30.</p><p>&quot;At this time, we can confirm the deaths of 30 U.S. citizens. We extend our deepest condolences to the victims and to the families of all those affected,&quot; the State Department said in a statement released Sunday. The U.S. is also aware of 13 missing citizens and has been in contact with their families.</p><p>Hamas militants stormed into Israel on Oct. 7 and murdered more than 1,400 Israelis, the vast majority of them civilians. The militants also kidnapped at least 155 people — a number that includes babies and the elderly — and are holding them hostage in Gaza. Their whereabouts are not publicly known, but their families have been urgently pressing for their release.</p><p>&quot;The U.S. government is working around the clock to determine their whereabouts and is working with the Israeli government on every aspect of the hostage crisis, including sharing intelligence and deploying experts from across the United States government to advise the Israeli government on hostage recovery efforts,&quot; the statement said.</p><p>The Gaza Health Ministry said 2,670 Palestinians have been killed so far.</p><p>— <em>Associated Press</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317537-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">7 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Foreign national Palestinians can cross the border to Egypt from Gaza starting Monday, Palestinian Embassy says</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317434" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Gazans with foreign passports wait at the Rafah Border Gate to cross into Egypt as Israel&#x27;s attacks on Gaza continue on the eighth day in Rafah, Gaza on October 14, 2023. </div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Anadolu Agency | Anadolu Agency | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>Palestinians who are foreign nationals will be allowed to cross the border into Egypt starting at 9 a.m. local time on Monday, according to a representative for the Embassy of Palestine. At the same time, humanitarian aid will also begin crossing into Gaza, Kamel Khatib, a representative for the Embassy of Palestine, <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/live-blog/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-gaza-israel-humanitarian-rcna120479#rcrd21487" target="_blank">told NBC News</a>.</p><p>— <em>Terri Cullen</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317534-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">7 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham warns Iran against escalating war </h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107307643" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) speaks alongside Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) during a press conference at the U.S. Capitol Building on September 27, 2023 in Washington, DC.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Anna Moneymaker | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., on Sunday warned Iran against escalating the war between Israel and Hamas, <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/lindsey-graham-iran-escalate-war-re-coming-rcna120500" target="_blank">NBC News reported</a>.</p><p>&quot;I want to applaud President Biden for his strong statement, and support of Israel. I just got off the phone with the Israelis. Their goal is to destroy Hamas in the south and try to save as many innocent Palestinians as possible to prevent escalation north from Hezbollah,&quot; Graham said in an interview on NBC News&#x27; &quot;Meet the Press&quot; on Sunday.</p><p>&quot;Here&#x27;s my message: If Hezbollah, which is a proxy of Iran, launches a massive attack on Israel, I would consider that a threat to the State of Israel, existential in nature.&quot;</p><p>Graham said he plans to introduce a resolution in the Senate to &quot;allow military action by the United States in conjunction with Israel to knock Iran out of the oil business,&quot; according to NBC News.</p><p>&quot;Iran, if you escalate this war, we&#x27;re coming for you,&quot; Graham added.</p><p><a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/lindsey-graham-iran-escalate-war-re-coming-rcna120500" target="_blank">Read the complete NBC News story here.</a></p><p>— <em>Annie Nova</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317532-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">8 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Senate leader Schumer says chamber will rush through military aid to Israel</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107316864" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">U.S. Capitol Police secure the U.S. Capitol in response to a call for a &quot;Day of Rage&quot; on October 13, 2023 in Washington, DC.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Win Mcnamee | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer said on Sunday that the senate would push through a military aid package to help Israel in its war against the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas.</p><p>&quot;We will work to move this aid through the senate ASAP, and the Israeli leaders made it clear to us they need the aid quickly,&quot; said Schumer during a trip to Israel.</p><p>He said among Israel&#x27;s requests are additional interceptors for its Iron Dome missile defense system, which has been operating non-stop shooting down Hamas rockets from Gaza, and precision munitions.</p><p>— <em>Reuters</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317524-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">8 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">More than 1,400 killed in Israel from surprise Hamas attack </h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317533" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Family and friends mourn Danielle, 25, and Noam, 26, an Israeli couple who were killed in a deadly attack by Hamas gunmen from Gaza as they attended a festival, as they are buried next to each other at their funeral in Kiryat Tivon, Israel, October 12, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Shir Torem | Reuters</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>The death toll in Israel from a surprise Hamas attack on Oct. 7 is now more than 1,400, the Israel Defense Forces told CNN on Sunday.</p><p>— <em>Annie Nova</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317523-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">9 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">FBI notes increase in threats against Jewish and Muslim communities</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107271243" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">FBI Director Christopher Wray testifies before a House Judiciary Committee hearing on &quot;oversight of the Federal Bureau of Investigation&quot; and alleged politicization of law enforcement, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., July 12, 2023. </div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Jonathan Ernst | Reuters</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>FBI officials say they&#x27;ve noticed an increase in threatening rhetoric targeting both the Jewish and Muslim communities in the week since the brutal Hamas attacks in Israel.</p><p>Director Chris Wray said on a call with reporters Sunday that the FBI is moving quickly to mitigate the threats and that the FBI does not discount the possibility that Hamas and other groups could exploit the conflict in the Middle East to call for or plot attacks in the United States.</p><p>A senior FBI official who spoke on condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the bureau said the majority of the threats that the FBI has responded to were not judged to be credible. But the official said the FBI takes them all seriously nonetheless.</p><p>The official also said that agents have been encouraged to be &quot;aggressive&quot; and proactive in communicating over the last week with faith-based leaders. The official said the purpose of that outreach is not to make anyone feel targeted but rather to ask clerics and others to report to law enforcement anything that seems suspicious.</p><p>Besides responding to an escalating number of threats, Wray said the FBI was also working through its legal attache office in Tel Aviv to do what it can to locate and identify Americans who remain unaccounted for after last weekend&#x27;s attacks.</p><p>— <em>Associated Press</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317516-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">10 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">U.S. State Department says flights out of Israel for Americans will continue Monday and Tuesday</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317337" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Travellers check the departure board at Ben Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv on October 14, 2023, amid the ongoing battles between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas. </div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Gil Cohen-magen | AFP | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>The U.S. Department of State on Sunday announced that the <a href="https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/situation-in-israel-2023.html" target="_blank">charter flights</a> out of Israel offered to American citizens will continue &quot;on a rolling basis&quot; on Monday and Tuesday.</p><p>The State Department set up the flights for U.S. citizens stranded in Israel, unable to leave due to the limited availability of commercial flights out of the country.</p><p>&quot;We urge those wishing to leave to take advantage of these charters while they are available,&quot; the department said in a statement.</p><p>Only U.S. citizens are eligible for the flights and must sign an agreement prior to departure that pledges to repay the U.S. government for the travel. The flights will leave from Israel&#x27;s Ben Gurion International Airport.</p><p>The department also provided details on how U.S. citizens in the Israeli city of Haifa can leave via a 10- to 12-hour ship ride to Cyprus on Monday. Those wishing to take the ship must arrive at Haifa port passenger terminal at 9 a.m. local time on Monday.</p><p>The U.S. government is still negotiating how to get American citizens in Gaza out of the region. It had secured a route of safe passage via the Rafah gate border crossing from Gaza to Egypt, but Americans trying to flee reportedly still have not been let through. In the meantime, the government is encouraging Americans in Gaza to fill out a <a href="https://cacms.state.gov/s/crisis-intake" target="_blank">crisis intake form</a> in case they need to be contacted on short notice.</p><p>The State Department has issued a <a href="https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/traveladvisories/israel-west-bank-and-gaza-travel-advisory.html" target="_blank">&quot;Do Not Travel&quot;</a> advisory for Gaza and &quot;Reconsider Travel&quot; advisories for Israel and the West Bank.</p><p>— <em>Rebecca Picciotto</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317515-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">10 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Death toll in Gaza rises to 2,450 </h2><div class="group"><p>The death toll in Gaza rose to 2,450 people and 9,200 injured, the Palestinian Ministry of Health in Gaza said. More than half of those killed, or 52% of them, were women and children, according to the ministry.</p><p>— <em>Annie Nova</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317508-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">11 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Chuck Schumer and visiting U.S. senators rushed to a Tel Aviv shelter during Hamas rocket attack </h2><div class="group"><p>U.S. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer said on social media that a bipartisan group of senators visiting Israel was rushed to a shelter in Tel Aviv on Sunday to wait out a rocket attack from Hamas. Schumer posted a photo of himself and Republican Sen. Mitt Romney of Utah in the shelter.</p><p>&quot;It shows you what Israelis have to go through. We must provide Israel with the support required to defend itself,&quot; Schumer said on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter.</p><span></span><p>Schumer, the highest-ranking Jewish elected official in the United States, took the trip to show support for Israel ahead of an expected request from President Joe Biden for Congress to approve wartime funding for Israel as well as Ukraine. Schumer, a Democrat, has said he would also hold discussions with Israeli officials what kind of support the country would need for both military and humanitarian operations.</p><p>Republican Sens. Bill Cassidy of Louisiana and Democratic Sens. Jacky Rosen of Nevada and Mark Kelly of Arizona were also on the trip.</p><p>— <em>Associated Press</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317513-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">11 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Iranian president warns war could expand if Israel&#x27;s siege of Gaza continues</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107304427" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi looks on during a press conference concluding his appearance at the United Nations General Assembly, in New York City, U.S., September 20, 2023. </div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Shannon Stapleton | Reuters</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>Iran&#x27;s hard-line president spoke with France&#x27;s leader on Sunday, warning that war would expand if Israel&#x27;s siege of Gaza doesn&#x27;t stop, state-run media reported.</p><p>The official IRNA news agency said Ebrahim Raisi and Emmanuel Macron spoke over the phone. The Iranian president made no mention of the unprecedented Oct. 7 incursion by Gaza&#x27;s militant Hamas group into southern Israel that sparked the latest Hamas-Israel war. Iran has long been a supporter of Hamas.</p><p>&quot;The situation will be complicated ... if the crimes by the Zionist regime, including the killing of people and blockade of Gaza, are not stopped,&quot; Raisi was quoted as saying, referring to Israel. IRNA did not provide further details.</p><p>Earlier, the Elysee Palace confirmed this weekend that Macron planned to talk to Raisi to urge Iran not to fuel tensions in the region or provide any operational support to Hamas.</p><p>Macron intended to press the argument that bringing the violence to a rapid end is in everyone&#x27;s interests, including Iran&#x27;s, the presidential office said. France feels that Iran can play a positive role in the crisis by simply not getting involved in it, either with &quot;words that are unacceptable&quot; or by supporting Hamas.</p><p>Over the weekend, Raisi also spoke with leaders of Arab nations of Iraq, Oman and Qatar and urged them to support Gaza&#x27;s Palestinians, Iranian media said.</p><p>He also accused Israel of perpetrating a &quot;genocide&quot; in Gaza and criticized the United States for its support of Israel.</p><p>— <em>Associated Press</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317511-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">11 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Blinken meets with Egyptian president, reiterates need for &#x27;safe passage&#x27; for Americans in Gaza</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317510" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken speaks to members of the media before leaving Cairo, Egypt, Sunday Oct. 15, 2023, en route to Jordan.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Jacquelyn Martin | Pool | via Reuters</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken met with Egypt&#x27;s President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi in Egypt on Sunday to discuss the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict and how to keep civilians safe amid the violence and lack of humanitarian aid in Gaza.</p><p>In the meeting, Blinken brought up the ongoing efforts to get American citizens in Gaza safely out of the region. The secretary had been trying to find a way for Americans to exit Gaza via the Rafah gate into Egypt, but those trying to leave have reported that the border crossing has remained closed.</p><p>&quot;Secretary Blinken reiterated to President El-Sisi the importance of facilitating the safe passage of American citizens and family members from Gaza,&quot; a spokesperson for Blinken said.</p><p>Over the past week, Blinken has been on a Middle East tour, trying to prevent the conflict from spreading throughout the region and to rally humanitarian support for civilians caught in the crossfire of the war.</p><p>Blinken has met with officials in Israel, Jordan, Qatar, Bahrain<strong>, </strong>Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Egypt. The State Department announced that he will return to Israel on Monday.</p><p>— <em>Rebecca Picciotto</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317498-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">13 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">White House national security advisor says Israel has turned water back on in some parts of Gaza</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107314767" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">White House National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan takes questions during the daily press briefing at the White House in Washington, D.C., on Oct. 10, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Jonathan Ernst | Reuters</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>White House National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan said Israel has reactivated the water pipes in southern Gaza after several days of cutting off the water supply in response to the deadly attack Hamas launched last weekend.</p><p>&quot;I have been in touch with my Israeli counterparts just within the last hour who reports to me that they have in fact turned the water pipe back on in southern Gaza,&quot; Sullivan said Sunday in an interview on CNN&#x27;s &quot;State of the Union.&quot;</p><p>&quot;That has been the subject of discussion over the course of the past few days,&quot; he added.</p><p>In a series of Sunday interviews, Sullivan reiterated the U.S. stance that all innocent civilians must be protected amid the violence of the Israel-Hamas conflict.</p><p>His comments come as many civilians remain trapped in Gaza without access to basic necessities like food, water, medicine and shelter.</p><p>&quot;The many, many Palestinians who have had nothing to do with the brutal terrorist organization among us the vast majority of the population of Gaza. They deserve dignity. They deserve safety and security,&quot; Sullivan said in an interview on NBC&#x27;s &quot;Meet the Press.&quot;</p><p>Sullivan also said the White House is &quot;working actively&quot; to get Americans in Gaza access to safe passage to leave the region, though those evacuation efforts have been thwarted by Hamas.</p><p>&quot;So far, we have not been able to get American citizens through the border crossing and I&#x27;m not aware of anyone else being able to get out at this time,&quot; he said.</p><p>— <em>Rebecca Picciotto</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317503-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">13 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">&quot;We did not ask for this war, but we will win it,&quot; Israeli Defense Forces&#x27; Peter Lerner says </h2><div class="group"><p>IDF spokesperson Lt. Col. Peter Lerner said on Sunday the military plans to strike Hamas from the top through its institutions, &quot;all the way down to the individuals that conducted the butchery of our babies.&quot;</p><p>&quot;We did not ask for this war, but we will win it,&quot; Lerner said on &quot;This Week&quot; on ABC.</p><p>He said they&#x27;ve instructed Gazans to evacuate the north &quot;to keep people out of harm&#x27;s way so that we can deal with Hamas.&quot; But he said Hamas was trying to interfere with those efforts.</p><p>&quot;They have no regard for human life, Israeli or Palestinian,&quot; he said.</p><p>Lerner also said that some of its forces have dispersed to communities along the border with Lebanon &quot;in anticipation for a potential uptick in violence with Hezbollah.&quot;</p><p>— <em>Annie Nova</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317502-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">13 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Israel urges Gazans south, as airstrikes continue ahead of ground assault</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed
