class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption"></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>The Israeli military said on Sunday it would continue to allow Gazans to evacuate south ahead of an expected ground assault by its forces on the Gaza Strip in retaliation for unprecedented attacks by Hamas militants eight days ago.</p><p>The army said hundreds of thousands had already moved south as Israel carried out the most intense bombardment the enclave has ever seen in response to the killing of 1,300 people in Israel, including 279 Israeli soldiers.</p><p>Authorities in Gaza said more than 2,300 people had been killed, a quarter of them children, and nearly 10,000 wounded so far. The enclave&#x27;s hospitals are running short of medical supplies and struggling to cope with the flow of injured.</p><p>— <em>Reuters</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317499-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">14 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Regional WHO chief appeals for the immediate reopening of Eqypt&#x27;s Rafah border crossing with Gaza</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317435" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Gazans with foreign passports wait at the Rafah Border Gate to cross into Egypt as Israel&#x27;s attacks on Gaza continue on the eighth day in Rafah, Gaza on October 14, 2023. </div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Anadolu Agency | Anadolu Agency | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>The regional head of the World Health Organization told The Associated Press on Sunday that evacuating hospitals from the northern part of the Gaza Strip is &quot;impossible&quot; and said Israel&#x27;s demand for the evacuation of medical facilities there goes against international law.</p><p>Ahmed Al-Mandhari said 22 hospitals with 2,000 patients in northern Gaza managed to move &quot;mobile patients&quot; to the south over the past two days but most of the patients can&#x27;t be evacuated.</p><p>&quot;It is really very risky, very dangerous if we push these hospitals to evacuate,&quot; he said in Cairo.</p><p>Egypt has yet to reach an agreement with Israel and Hamas to reopen the Rafah border crossing to deliver medical supplies and other humanitarian aid territory to the besieged, Hamas-ruled strip.</p><p>Al-Mandhari urged for the reopening &quot;immediately, with no delay.&quot; The U.N. health agency has supplies waiting in Egypt, around 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the Rafah crossing but cannot take them inside, he said.</p><p>Rafah was shuttered early on Tuesday after Israeli airstrikes hit close to Gaza&#x27;s side of the crossing.</p><p>— <em>Associated Press</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317488-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">15 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Egypt&#x27;s President Sisi in talks to get aid to Gaza, presidency says</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107219255" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi at the United Nations in New York on September 25, 2019. Egypt&#x27;s economy and infrastructure has been under the folds of the Egyptian Armed Forces ever since the former general took over almost a decade ago.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Angela Weiss | Afp | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>Egypt&#x27;s president Abdel Fattah al-Sisi is in talks with international and regional partners to enable aid deliveries into Gaza and to de-escalate the fighting there, his office said on Sunday.</p><p>Israeli bombardments on the Gaza side of the Rafah crossing into Egypt, the main crossing out of Gaza not controlled by Israel, have disrupted operations there.</p><p>Aid from several countries has been building up in Egypt&#x27;s Sinai peninsula due to a failure to reach a deal enabling its safe delivery to Gaza and enabling evacuations of some foreign passport holders through the Rafah crossing into Egypt.</p><p>U.N. aid chief Martin Griffiths said on Saturday that the humanitarian situation in Gaza is &quot;fast becoming untenable&quot;.</p><p>The statement from Sisi&#x27;s office also said Egypt rejected any plan to displace Palestinians &quot;to the detriment of other countries,&quot; and said Egypt&#x27;s own security was a red line.</p><p>Sisi also proposed a summit to discuss the crisis, according to the statement.</p><p>— <em>Reuters</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317484-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">15 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Blinken will return to Israel after stops in Arab nations aimed at avoiding a broader conflict</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317423" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken waves as he arrives in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Saturday, Oct. 14, 2023, after making a day trip to the United Arab Emirates. </div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Jacquelyn Martin | Reuters</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken will return to Israel this week after completing a frantic six-country rush through Arab nations aimed at preventing the Israel-Hamas war from igniting a broader regional conflict.</p><p>The U.S. State Department announced Blinken&#x27;s plan to travel Monday to Israel — his second visit in five days — as America&#x27;s top diplomat arrived in Cairo for talks Sunday with Egypt&#x27;s president, Abdel Fattah al-Sisi. It was the last of Blinken&#x27;s meetings with Arab leaders amid increasing fears that an impending Israeli ground offensive into Gaza could spark a wider war with devastating humanitarian consequences.</p><p>Department spokesman Matthew Miller told reporters traveling with Blinken that the secretary was returning to Tel Aviv &quot;for further consultations with Israeli officials.&quot; Miller did not elaborate.</p><p>Before landing in Egypt, Blinken met on Sunday morning with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Riyadh. That meeting followed talks over the previous three days with the leaders of the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Qatar, Jordan and the Palestinian Authority.</p><p>— <em>Associated Press</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317483-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">15 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Pope Francis renews his call for the release of Israeli hostages held by Hamas</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107293117" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Pope Francis photographed on August 9, 2023, in Vatican City.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Vatican Pool | Getty Images News | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>Pope Francis on Sunday renewed his call for the release of Israeli hostages held by Gaza&#x27;s militant Hamas rulers and called for humanitarian corridors to help those under siege in Gaza.</p><p>&quot;I continue to follow with much sorrow what is happening in Israel and Palestine,&quot; Francis said during his Sunday&#x27;s Angelus prayer in St. Peter&#x27;s Square. &quot;I think back to the many people, especially the little ones and the elderly.&quot;</p><p>The Pope reiterated his appeal for the release of scores of Israeli hostages snatched during Hamas&#x27; deadly incursion into southern Israel last weekend and taken to Gaza.</p><p>&quot;I strongly ask that the children, the elderly, women and all civilians don&#x27;t become victims of the conflict,&quot; Francis said. He added that humanitarian law must be respected, &quot;especially in Gaza where there is an urgent need to guarantee humanitarian corridors and to rescue the entire population.&quot;</p><p>The Pope appealed for the world not to &quot;shed any more innocent blood, neither in the Holy Land, nor in Ukraine, nor anywhere else. Enough! Wars are always a defeat, always.&quot;</p><p>— <em>Associated Press</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317481-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">15 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Thousands march in Moroccan capital in support of Gaza Palestinians</h2><div class="group"><p>Thousands took the streets of the Moroccan capital on Sunday to rally in support of Palestinians in Gaza and denounce Israel&#x27;s actions in the latest war with Gaza&#x27;s militant Hamas rulers.</p><p>Waving Palestinian flags, the rally also marked a major showing for the banned Islamist movement Al Adl Wa Ihssane, which supports Hamas. After Hamas&#x27;s unprecedented and deadly Oct. 7 incursion into Israel, Morocco issued a statement condemning the violence. Royal Air Maroc, temporarily cancelled flights from Casablanca to Tel Aviv — a route that began in 2021.</p><p>Demonstrators marched in central Rabat and threw smoke bombs and fireworks as riot police stood between them and the Parliament building and other landmarks.</p><p>Hassan Ait Amar, a 52-year-old from Casablanca, carried a sign demanding Morocco&#x27;s lawmakers revoke a normalization of ties with Israel.</p><p>&quot;If they want peace, they (Israel) should respect Palestinians, international law and a two-state solution,&quot; he said.</p><p>Israel and Morocco normalized relations as part of the 2020 Abraham Accords, a series of diplomatic agreements between Israel and four Arab countries brokered by then-President Donald Trump. Israel is home to a large community of Jews of Moroccan descent. Morocco and Israel have agreed to military cooperation and boosted trade.</p><p>— <em>Associated Press</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317475-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">17 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">EU to hold emergency meeting on Tuesday to discuss Israel-Hamas war</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317477" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Charles Michel, president of the European Council, rings a bell at an informal meeting of European Union (EU) leaders in Granada, Spain, on Friday, Oct. 6, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Bloomberg | Bloomberg | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>The European Union on Tuesday will hold an extraordinary meeting of its member states to discuss the fallout of the escalating Israel-Hamas conflict and the potential consequences for the bloc. </p><p>European Council President Charles Michel <a href="https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2023/10/14/invitation-letter-by-president-charles-michel-to-the-members-of-the-european-council-ahead-of-their-video-conference-of-17-october-2023/" target="_blank">said</a> in an invitation letter issued Saturday that it was of the &quot;utmost importance&quot; to establish a &quot;clear unified course of action that reflects the complexity of the unfolding situation.&quot;</p><p>&quot;If we are not careful, it has the potential to exacerbate tensions between communities and feed extremism&quot; in the European Union, Michel said.</p><p>&quot;There is a major risk of migration and movements of a large number of people to neighboring countries which already have a significant number of refugees on their territory. If not handled carefully, there is a risk of onward migratory waves to Europe,&quot; he added. </p><p><em>— Sam Meredith</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317474-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">17 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Germany issues travel warning for Israel, Palestinian territories and Lebanon</h2><div class="group"><p>Germany&#x27;s Foreign Office said Sunday that it had decided to issue a travel warning for Israel, the Palestinian territories and Lebanon. </p><p>&quot;We urgently appeal to refrain from traveling to these countries and areas. In general, a travel warning is only issued if there is danger to life,&quot; the German Foreign Office <a href="https://twitter.com/GermanyDiplo/status/1713471249995723117" target="_blank">said</a> in a post via X, formerly known as Twitter. </p><p>The ministry also urged people already in these areas to register themselves with the German government. </p><p><em>— Sam Meredith</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317472-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">17 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">UK wants to minimize Palestinian and Israeli casualties, foreign minister says</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317473" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Foreign Secretary James Cleverly speaks to the media outside BBC Broadcasting House in London, after appearing on the BBC One current affairs programme, Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Jonathan Brady - Pa Images | Pa Images | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>British Foreign Minister James Cleverly says he has not specifically asked Israel to wait until Palestinian civilians have moved to the south of Gaza before carrying outs its expected military operation. </p><p>&quot;I haven&#x27;t asked that specific request because Hamas are trying to prevent people leaving northern Gaza,&quot; Cleverly <a href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/uk-politics-67105018" target="_blank">told the BBC</a> Sunday morning. </p><p>&quot;Of course, we want to minimize Palestinian casualties, we want to minimize Israeli casualties. We want everybody to respect civilians, but the real clear distinction is Israel are trying to get civilians out of danger, Hamas are trying to put civilians into danger and that is a fundamental difference between the two,&quot; he added. </p><p>The Palestinian militant group of Hamas, which rules the Gaza Strip, has told citizens to ignore Israel&#x27;s evacuation order. The United Nations has said the evacuation order is not possible and warned of &quot;devastating humanitarian consequences.&quot; </p><p><em>— Sam Meredith</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317470-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">18 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Israeli military says Lebanese border is now &#x27;strictly&#x27; off-limits</h2><div class="group"><p>The Israel Defense Forces said it has isolated the area within 4 kilometers (2.5 miles) of the country&#x27;s border with Lebanon.</p><p>IDF spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the move was taken in response to shooting from Lebanon at Israeli territory.</p><p>&quot;Following the assessment of the situation and the shooting incident in the north, it was decided to isolate the area of ​​up to four kilometers from the northern border with Lebanon,&quot; Hagari <a href="https://twitter.com/IDFSpokesperson/status/1713461249931923797" target="_blank">said on X</a>, formerly known as Twitter, according to a Google translation.</p><p>&quot;The IDF clarifies that entering the area is strictly prohibited and asks the public to be vigilant and not to enter the area.&quot;</p><p>He added that the Israeli military was undertaking &quot;proactive GPS jamming&quot; in the area, which could affect location-based apps.</p><p>—<em> Katrina Bishop</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317462-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">18 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Palestinian citizens flee their homes as Israel prepares next stage of military operations </h2><div class="group"><p>Images published Sunday showed Palestinian citizens leaving their homes as Israel&#x27;s military prepares for its next stage of operations.</p></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317467" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">A Palestinian boy carries his pet bird in a cage as families leave their homes in the southern of Gaza Strip on Oct. 15, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Mohammed Abed | Afp | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317468" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Palestinian families flee their homes following an Israeli attack on the Rafah refugee camp.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Mohammed Abed | Afp | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p><em>— Sam Meredith, Getty Images</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317463-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">19 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Israeli citizens evacuate city of Sderot near Gaza</h2><div class="group"><p>Israeli citizens on Sunday were seen placing their bags on board a bus in the city of Sderot as they evacuated in search of safer areas amid the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict. </p><p>The city is located close to the Gaza border. </p></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317465" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Israelis place their bags on board a bus as they evacuate from the Israeli city of Sderot to safer areas in the state of Israel on Oct. 15, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Jack Guez | Afp | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317464" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Israelis board a bus in the city of Sderot as battles between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas continue.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Jack Guez | Afp | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p><em>— Sam Meredith, Getty Images</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317461-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">19 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Deadliest week on record for journalists covering Israel-Palestine, NGO says</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107314390" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Israeli journalists take cover during a rocket attack from Gaza in the southern Israeli kibbutz of Kfar Aza near the border with the Palestinian territory, on October 10, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Jack Guez | AFP | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>The president of the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), a U.S. non-governmental organization that promotes press freedom, <a href="https://cpj.org/2023/10/journalist-casualties-in-the-israel-gaza-conflict/" target="_blank">said</a> the last week has been the deadliest on record for journalists covering Israel-Palestine.</p><p>As of Saturday, 12 journalists had been killed, eight were injured and two were missing over the course of the first eight days of the Israel-Hamas war, the CPJ said in an update via its website.</p><p>Of the journalists confirmed to have been killed, the CPJ said 10 were Palestinian, one was Israeli and a Beirut-based journalist was killed during a shelling attack in southern Lebanon.</p><p>&quot;This is the deadliest week ever for journalists covering Israel-Palestine in the more than 30 years that @pressfreedom has been covering attacks on the press,&quot; Jodie Ginsberg, president of the CPJ, <a href="https://twitter.com/jodieginsberg/status/1713303397846089831" target="_blank">said</a> Saturday via X, formerly known as Twitter.</p><p><em>— Sam Meredith</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317458-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">19 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">U.S. offers Americans in Israel sea evacuation on Monday</h2><div class="group"><p>The U.S. Embassy in Israel <a href="https://il.usembassy.gov/security-alert-10/" target="_blank">said</a> it would help Americans and their immediate family members with valid travel documents to depart the northern Israeli port city of Haifa via sea to Cyprus on Monday.</p><p>In a security alert posted on its website Sunday, the embassy said boarding for passengers would begin at 8 a.m. local time (1 a.m. ET) and U.S. citizens must arrive at Haifa Port&#x27;s passenger terminal no later than 9 a.m. local time.</p><p>&quot;Boarding will proceed in order of arrival and is on a space limited basis,&quot; the embassy said.</p><p>The alert listed <a href="https://il.usembassy.gov/security-alert-10/" target="_blank">several instructions</a> for travelers and noted the passage to Limassol Port in Cyprus was expected to take roughly 10-12 hours.</p><p><em>— Sam Meredith</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317457-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">20 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">IDF says no operations in northern Gaza from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. local time</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317455" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Palestinian citizens inspect damage to their homes caused by Israeli airstrikes on October 14, 2023 in Gaza City, Gaza. Many Gazan citizens have fled to the south following warnings from the Israeli government to do so.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Ahmad Hasaballah | Getty Images News | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>Israel Defense Forces said Sunday in a message addressed to residents of Gaza City and northern Gaza that it won&#x27;t carry out any military operations from 10 a.m. local time (3 a.m. ET) to 1 p.m., renewing its call for people to move southward. </p><p>&quot;Residents of Gaza City and northern Gaza, in the past days, we&#x27;ve urged you to relocate to the southern area for your safety. We want to inform you that the IDF will not carry out any operations along this route from 10 AM to 1 PM,&quot; the IDF <a href="https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1713453410534543518" target="_blank">said in a post via X</a>, formerly known as Twitter. </p><p>&quot;Your safety and that of your families matters. Please follow our instructions and head southward,&quot; it added. </p><p>The United Nations has <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/13/civilians-trapped-in-gaza-cant-escape-israels-siege.html">criticized</a> Israel&#x27;s military for issuing an evacuation order to 1.1 million people in northern Gaza, saying it is &quot;impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences.&quot; </p><p><em>— Sam Meredith</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317454-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">22 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Death toll in Gaza crosses 2,300</h2><div class="group"><p><em>EDITORS NOTE-Graphic content- Image shows body bags of those killed in Gaza.</em> </p><p>More than 2,300 people have been killed and another 9,000 injured in Gaza, according to the <a href="https://www.facebook.com/MOHGaza1994/" target="_blank">local health ministry&#x27;s latest update</a>.</p></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317381" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Mourners pray over the shrouded bodies of members of the Agha family, killed in an Israeli strike in Khan Yunis in the Gaza Strip, during their funeral on October 14, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Mahmud Hams | AFP | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>In Israel, at least 1,300 have been killed and 3,300 wounded, according to public broadcaster Kan.</p><p><em>— Christine Wang</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317453-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">23 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Blinken to meet with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317423" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken waves as he arrives in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Saturday, Oct. 14, 2023, after making a day trip to the United Arab Emirates. </div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Jacquelyn Martin | Reuters</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken is set to meet with Saudi Arabia&#x27;s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Riyadh at 7:30 a.m. local time (12:30 a.m. ET), a U.S. official said.</p><p>The meeting comes as Blinken is scheduled to depart for Egypt later in the day, where he is expected to discuss a tentative agreement to grant Americans in Gaza safe passage through the Rafah border crossing.</p><p><em>— Christine Wang</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317448-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">24 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">UN agency calls for protection of civilians in its shelters, including those in northern Gaza</h2><div class="group"><p>The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East called on Israeli authorities to <a href="https://www.unrwa.org/newsroom/official-statements/unrwa-urgently-calls-protect-civilians" target="_blank">protect all civilians</a> in its shelters across the Gaza Strip, including those in northern Gaza and Gaza City.</p></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317471" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Internally displaced Palestinians rest as they take refuge in a United Nations school, in the Rafah refugee camp, in the southern of Gaza Strip on October 14, 2023, as fighting between Israel and the Hamas movement continues for the eighth consecutive day in the Gaza Strip enclave.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Mohammed Abed | Afp | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>The UNRWA warned that despite Israel&#x27;s order to evacuate the north, many people will not be able to flee, particularly pregnant women, children, the elderly, and people with disabilities.</p><p>&quot;UNRWA shelters in Gaza and northern Gaza are no longer safe. This is unprecedented,&quot; it said.</p><p>&quot;This war should be no exception, protection of civilians and civilian infrastructure, including United Nations buildings, applies to this conflict too.&quot;</p><p>Israel has ordered roughly 1 million residents in northern Gaza to evacuate to the south ahead of an anticipated ground offensive.</p></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317432" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Palestinians fill water bottles and take them home as a UN report states that more than 2 million people struggle with water shortage, in Khan Younis, Gaza on October 14, 2023. </div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Mustafa Hassona | Anadolu Agency | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>Separately, the UNRWA warned that <a href="https://www.unrwa.org/newsroom/official-statements/matter-life-and-death-water-runs-out-2-million-people-gaza" target="_blank">2 million people are at risk as water runs out</a> in Gaza and called for humanitarian supplies to be let in. It said its newly relocated base in the south is also running out of water as it takes in refugees, thousands of whom it said followed the evacuation order.</p><p>UNRWA Commissioner-General Philippe Lazzarini said fuel needs to be brought in immediately to guarantee safe drinking water.</p><p>&quot;If not, people will start dying of severe dehydration, among them young children, the elderly and women. Water is now the last remaining lifeline. I appeal for the siege on humanitarian assistance to be lifted now,&quot; he said.</p><p><em>— Christine Wang</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317447-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">Sat, Oct 14 2023<span class="LiveBlogTimestamp-datetimeDivider"></span>11:21 PM EDT</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">IDF renews calls for residents to evacuate to southern Gaza</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317340" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Palestinians with their belongings leave Gaza City as they flee from their homes following the Israeli army&#x27;s warning on October 13, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Mahmud Hams | AFP | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>The Israel Defense Forces reiterated its call for residents to evacuate to southern Gaza, <a href="https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1713374444612378647" target="_blank">in a post on X</a>, the social media platform formerly known as Twitter.</p><p>Earlier, the <a href="https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1713362078604382696" target="_blank">military posted another video</a> listing other acts committed by Hamas, saying the Palestinian militant group &quot;has shown the world time and time again what they are capable of.&quot;</p><p>&quot;Now the IDF is prepared to counter with an even greater force. There is no place in the world for terrorism,&quot; it said.</p><p>The posts come as Israel is expected to commence a ground offensive in Gaza.</p><p><em>— Christine Wang</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317408-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">Sat, Oct 14 2023<span class="LiveBlogTimestamp-datetimeDivider"></span>1:27 PM EDT</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Israel Defense Forces says its preparing for &#x27;wide range&#x27; offensive</h2><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317334" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Israel continues to deploy soldiers and armored vehicles along the Gaza border in Zikim kibbutz of Ashkelon, Israel on October 14, 2023. </div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Mostafa Alkharouf | Anadolu Agency | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>The Israel Defense Forces, or IDF, said it was &quot;preparing to implement a wide range of offensive operative plans&quot; which will include &quot;an integrated and coordinated attack from the air, sea and land&quot; against Hamas.</p><p>The IDF added that it had already completed its mobilization of hundreds of thousands of servicemen for the counteroffensive, according to a <a href="https://www.idf.il/134481" target="_blank">statement translated by NBC News</a>.</p></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107317349" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Israeli soldiers prepare armed drones stationed close to the Palestinian Gaza Strip enclave, from a field near the southern Israeli city of Sderot, on October 14, 2023, as fighting between Israel and the Hamas movement continues for the eighth consecutive day.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Thomas Coex | AFP | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p>&quot;IDF battalions and soldiers are deployed all over the country and are prepared to increase readiness for the next stages of the war — with an emphasis on a significant ground operation,&quot; the statement added.</p></div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbed" id="ArticleBody-InlineImage-107313516" data-test="InlineImage"><div class="InlineImage-wrapper"><div class="InlineImage-imagePlaceholder" style="padding-bottom:55.55555555555556%"><div style="height:100%" class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div><div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCaption">Israeli soldiers in an armoured vehicles drive along a street near northern town of Kiryat Shmona close to the border with Lebanon on October 9, 2023.</div><div class="InlineImage-imageEmbedCredit">Jalaa  Marey | AFP | Getty Images</div></div></div></div><div class="group"><p><em>— Amanda Macias</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317446-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">Sat, Oct 14 2023<span class="LiveBlogTimestamp-datetimeDivider"></span>11:06 PM EDT</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Deal to allow Americans out of Gaza through Rafah gate faces obstacles, officials say</h2><div class="group"><p>The tentative agreement to grant Americans in Gaza safe passage into Egypt through the Rafah gate continues to face significant obstacles to implementation, <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/live-blog/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-gaza-hit-shelling-israel-defends-evacuat-rcna120419/rcrd21416?canonicalCard=true" target="_blank">U.S. officials told NBC News</a>.</p><p>Previous discussions between Egypt, the U.S., Qatar and Israel looked set to allow Americans across the border crossing during a five-hour window Saturday, but NBC reports the deadline came and went without any immediate sign of success. One official told NBC the parties are continuing to negotiate.</p><p>Secretary of State Antony Blinken is expected to land in Cairo on Sunday and the deal is set to be a key issue on his agenda.</p><p>While sticking points remain, the State Department has urged the estimated 500 to 600 Americans in Gaza to move south, warning that if the crossing opens, the window could be brief.</p><p><em>— NBC News, Christine Wang</em></p></div><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postDivider"></div></div><div id="107317450-post" class="LiveBlogBody-post"><div class="group LiveBlogBody-postTimestamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-liveBlogTimeStamp"><div class="LiveBlogTimestamp-timeHidden"><span></span><time data-testid="lastpublished-timestamp">23 Hours Ago</time></div></div></div><h2 class="LiveBlogBody-subtitle">Read CNBC’s previous live coverage here</h2><div class="group"><p><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/14/israel-hamas-gaza-live-updates.html">IDF is preparing for &#x27;a coordinated attack from the air, sea and land&#x27; against Hamas in Gaza</a></p></div><div target="_blank"><span class="icon-social_rss"></span></a></li></ul><div class="CNBCFooter-info"><div class="CNBCFooter-newsAndAdvertiseSection"><div class="CNBCFooter-section"><h4 class="CNBCFooter-smallHeader">News Tips</h4><p class="CNBCFooter-sectionInfo">Got a confidential news tip? Global Business and Financial News, Stock Quotes, and Market Data and Analysis.</p><div class="CNBCFooter-marketData"><a href="/market-data-terms-of-service/">Market Data Terms of Use and Disclaimers</a></div><p class="CNBCFooter-copyright">Data also provided by<!-- --> <a href="//www.cnbc.com/market-data-terms-of-service/"><img class="CNBCFooter-reutersLogo" src="https://static-redesign.cnbcfm.com/dist/09c161b9810767a7849e.svg" alt="Reuters"/></a></p></div></div></div></div></footer></div><div class="UniversalVideoPlayer-videoContainer  paused   " style="top:-3000px;bottom:;left:-3000px;transform:;transform-origin:;transition:;position:;transition-property:;opacity:"></div><div class="App-proContentRecommendation"></div></div></div><script charSet="UTF-8">
window._comscore = [];
var EEA_REGION_COUNTRY_CODES = [ "AT", "BE", "BG", "HR", "CY", "CZ", "DK", "EE", "FI", "FR", "DE", "GR", "HU", "IS", "IE", "IT", "LV", "LI", "LT", "LU", "MT", "NL", "NO", "PL", "PT", "RO", "SK", "SI", "ES", "SE", "CH", "TR", "GB" ];
var OneTrustCategories = {
  STRICTLY_NECESSARY: 1,
  TARGETED_ADS: 4,
  STORAGE: 6,
  CONTENT_SELECTION_AND_MEASUREMENT: 7,
  SOCIAL_MEDIA: 8,
}
var initiateComscore = {
  pushData: function(cs_ucfr) {
      var data = {
        c1: '2',
        c2: '1000004',
        options: { url_append: 'comscorekw=Politics' },
        cs_ucfr: cs_ucfr
      };
      window._comscore.push(data);
      initiateComscore.addScripts();
  },

  addScripts: function() {
      (function() {
          var s = document.createElement("script"),
              el = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
          s.async = true;
          s.src = 'https://sb.scorecardresearch.com/beacon.js';
          el && el.parentNode.insertBefore(s, el);
      })();
  },

  getCookie: function(cookieName) {
    return document &&
      document.cookie &&
      document.cookie
        .split(';')
        .map((s) => s.trim())
        .find((s) => s.startsWith(cookieName));
  },

  fetchRegion: function() {
    fetch('https://geo.cnbc.com/info/')
        .then(response => response.json())
          .then(data => {
            if (data && data.geo && data.geo.country_code) {
              if(EEA_REGION_COUNTRY_CODES.includes(data.geo.country_code)) {
                initiateComscore.pushData('0');
              } else {
                initiateComscore.pushData('');
              }
            }
          });
  },

  run: function() {
      if (!Object.values(OneTrustCategories).includes(7)) {
        throw new Error('OneTrust category not found.');
      }
      var optanonCookie = initiateComscore.getCookie('OptanonConsent');
      var usPrivacyCookie = initiateComscore.getCookie('USPrivacy');
      var regionCookie = initiateComscore.getCookie('region');

      // check if regionCookie is present if not fetch region and update cs_ucfr value;
      if (regionCookie) {
        // if region is USA check for USPrivacy Cookie
        if (regionCookie.split('=')[1] === 'USA') {
          var usPrivacyCookieValue = usPrivacyCookie && usPrivacyCookie.split('=')[1];
          if (optanonCookie || usPrivacyCookieValue) {
            if (usPrivacyCookieValue === '1YYN') {
              initiateComscore.pushData('0');
            } else if (usPrivacyCookieValue === '1YNN') {
              initiateComscore.pushData('1');
            } else { // if USPrivacy cookie is not present
              initiateComscore.pushData('1');
            }
          } else {
            initiateComscore.fetchRegion();
          }
        } else {
          // If region is not USA check for OptanonCookie
          if (optanonCookie) {
            var categoryRegex = /groups=[^&]*%2C7%3A([01])/;
            var regexResults = optanonCookie.match(categoryRegex);
            if (regexResults && regexResults[1]) {
              initiateComscore.pushData(regexResults[1]);
            } else {
              initiateComscore.pushData('0');
            }
          } else {
            initiateComscore.fetchRegion();
          }
        }
      } else {
        initiateComscore.fetchRegion();
      }
  }
};
//Run COMSCORE
initiateComscore.run();
</script><noscript><img alt="comscore" src="https://sb.scorecardresearch.com/p?c1=2&c2=1000004&cv=2.0&cj=1" /></noscript><script Brent futures fell 36 cents, or 0.4%, to $90.53 per barrel and U.S. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude dropped 37 cents, or 0.4%, to $87.32 a barrel by 2215 GMT on Sunday. Both benchmarks rose nearly 6% on Friday, posting their highest daily percentage gains since April, as investors priced in the possibility of a wider Middle East conflict. Brent also recorded a weekly gain of 7.5%, its biggest such increase since February. WTI climbed 5.9% for the week. The conflict in the Middle East has had little impact on global oil and gas supplies, and Israel is not a big producer. But investors and market observers are assessing how the conflict could escalate and what it might mean for supplies from nearby countries in the world's top oil-producing region. — Reuters","body":{"content":[{"tagName":"image","attributes":{"id":"107275183","type":"image","creatorOverwrite":"Christopher Furlong | Getty Images News | Getty Images","headline":"GP: Middle East Instability Props Oil Price Close to All Time High 232207","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fimage.cnbcfm.com\u002Fapi\u002Fv1\u002Fimage\u002F107275183-1690003700866-gettyimages-51643968-51613615CF012_oil.jpeg?v=1697410400","caption":"Oil prices are expected to increase in the second half of 2023, according to the International Energy Forum.","copyrightHolder":"Christopher Furlong | Getty Images News | Getty Images","width":"3000","height":"2010","altText":"Oil prices are expected to increase in the second half of 2023, according to the International Energy Forum."},"data":{"__typename":"image"},"children":[],"__typename":"bodyContent"},{"tagName":"div","attributes":{"className":["group"]},"data":{"__typename":"asset"},"children":[{"tagName":"p","children":["Oil prices eased in early Asia trade on Monday, reversing last Friday's rally as investors waited to see if the Israel-Hamas conflict draws in other countries, which could drive up prices further and deal a fresh blow to the global economy."]},{"tagName":"p","children":["Brent futures fell 36 cents, or 0.4%, to $90.53 per barrel and U.S. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude dropped 37 cents, or 0.4%, to $87.32 a barrel by 2215 GMT on Sunday."]},{"tagName":"p","children":["Both benchmarks rose nearly 6% on Friday, posting their highest daily percentage gains since April, as investors priced in the possibility of a wider Middle East conflict."]},{"tagName":"p","children":["Brent also recorded a weekly gain of 7.5%, its biggest such increase since February. Futures tied to the Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.05%, while S & P 500 futures and Nasdaq-100 futures gained 0.07% and 0.17%, respectively. Oil prices s piked more than 5% during Friday's session and posted their best day since April as the conflict between Israel and Hamas fueled some fears related to oil production in the region. Some on Wall Street are bracing for more volatility into year-end as yields and oil prices rise, inflation remains sticky, and conflict ensues in the Middle East, said Eric Johnston, Cantor Fitzgerald's head of equity derivatives and cross-asset. \"This Mideast situation is kind of showing that when you own equities, you are taking risks,\" he told CNBC's \" Closing Bell \" on Friday. \"As a result, you need to have good upside returns in order to justify that risk, because there are things that come out of nowhere, like this situation.\" Over the weekend , Israel's military continued urging residents to evacuate northern Gaza amid a widely anticipated ground invasion. Meanwhile, U.S. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said Sunday that the Senate would work to quickly push through a military aid package to assist Israel as it battles Hamas. Officers found the 32-year-old woman and 6-year-old boy late Saturday morning at a home in an unincorporated area of Plainfield Township, southwest of Chicago, the Will County Sheriff's Office said in a statement on social media. The statement added that the boy was pronounced dead at a hospital and the woman had multiple stab wounds and was expected to survive. An autopsy on the child showed he had also been stabbed multiple times. \"Detectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,\" the sheriff's statement said. According to the sheriff's office, the woman had called 911 to report that her landlord had attacked her with a knife, adding she then ran into a bathroom and continued to fight him off. The boy was stabbed numerous times with a knife, according to an autopsy, the sheriff's office said. The woman had more than a dozen stab wounds and remained hospitalized Sunday and was expected to survive. The Chicago office of the Council on American-Islamic Relations held a news conference later Sunday with a family member and knew their identities. It said text messages exchanged among family members showed the attacker had made disparaging remarks about Muslims. We extend our deepest condolences to the victims and to the families of all those affected,\" the State Department said in a statement released Sunday. The U.S. is also aware of 13 missing citizens and has been in contact with their families. Hamas militants stormed into Israel on Oct. 7 and murdered more than 1,400 Israelis, the vast majority of them civilians. The militants also kidnapped at least 155 people — a number that includes babies and the elderly — and are holding them hostage in Gaza. Their whereabouts are not publicly known, but their families have been urgently pressing for their release. \"The U.S. government is working around the clock to determine their whereabouts and is working with the Israeli government on every aspect of the hostage crisis, including sharing intelligence and deploying experts from across the United States government to advise the Israeli government on hostage recovery efforts,\" the statement said. Director Chris Wray said on a call with reporters Sunday that the FBI is moving quickly to mitigate the threats and that the FBI does not discount the possibility that Hamas and other groups could exploit the conflict in the Middle East to call for or plot attacks in the United States. A senior FBI official who spoke on condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the bureau said the majority of the threats that the FBI has responded to were not judged to be credible. But the official said the FBI takes them all seriously nonetheless. The official also said that agents have been encouraged to be \"aggressive\" and proactive in communicating over the last week with faith-based leaders. The official said the purpose of that outreach is not to make anyone feel targeted but rather to ask clerics and others to report to law enforcement anything that seems suspicious. Besides responding to an escalating number of threats, Wray said the FBI was also working through its legal attache office in Tel Aviv to do what it can to locate and identify Americans who remain unaccounted for after last weekend's attacks. — Associated Press","body":{"content":[{"tagName":"image","attributes":{"id":"107271243","type":"image","creatorOverwrite":"Jonathan Ernst | Reuters","headline":"RT: Christopher Wray: FBI Director Christopher Wray testifies before a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington - 107271243","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fimage.cnbcfm.com\u002Fapi\u002Fv1\u002Fimage\u002F107271243-16892685552023-07-12t165406z_1403545678_rc2s12ape9i8_rtrmadp_0_usa-justice-congress.jpeg?v=1697395334","caption":"FBI Director Christopher Wray testifies before a House Judiciary Committee hearing on \"oversight of the Federal Bureau of Investigation\" and alleged politicization of law enforcement, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., July 12, 2023. ","copyrightHolder":"Jonathan Ernst | Reuters","width":"3500","height":"2416","altText":"FBI Director Christopher Wray testifies before a House Judiciary Committee hearing on \"oversight of the Federal Bureau of Investigation\" and alleged politicization of law enforcement, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., July 12, 2023. The State Department set up the flights for U.S. citizens stranded in Israel, unable to leave due to the limited availability of commercial flights out of the country. \"We urge those wishing to leave to take advantage of these charters while they are available,\" the department said in a statement. Only U.S. citizens are eligible for the flights and must sign an agreement prior to departure that pledges to repay the U.S. government for the travel. The flights will leave from Israel's Ben Gurion International Airport. The department also provided details on how U.S. citizens in the Israeli city of Haifa can leave via a 10- to 12-hour ship ride to Cyprus on Monday. Those wishing to take the ship must arrive at Haifa port passenger terminal at 9 a.m. local time on Monday. The U.S. government is still negotiating how to get American citizens in Gaza out of the region. It had secured a route of safe passage via the Rafah gate border crossing from Gaza to Egypt, but Americans trying to flee reportedly still have not been let through. In the meantime, the government is encouraging Americans in Gaza to fill out a crisis intake form in case they need to be contacted on short notice. The State Department has issued a \"Do Not Travel\" advisory for Gaza and \"Reconsider Travel\" advisories for Israel and the West Bank. — Rebecca Picciotto","body":{"content":[{"tagName":"image","attributes":{"id":"107317337","type":"image","creatorOverwrite":"Gil Cohen-magen | AFP | Getty Images","headline":"GP: Israel-Hamas War Tel Aviv: Travellers check the departure board at Ben Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv on October 14, 2023, amid the ongoing battles between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas.","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fimage.cnbcfm.com\u002Fapi\u002Fv1\u002Fimage\u002F107317337-1697283085075-gettyimages-1723268809-AFP_33YA4ZJ.jpeg?v=1697392533","caption":"Travellers check the departure board at Ben Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv on October 14, 2023, amid the ongoing battles between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas. ","copyrightHolder":"Gil Cohen-magen | AFP | Getty Images","width":"5398","height":"3599","altText":"EDITORS NOTE: Graphic content \u002F Travellers check the departure board at Ben Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv on October 14, 2023, amid the ongoing battles between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas. The official IRNA news agency said Ebrahim Raisi and Emmanuel Macron spoke over the phone. The Iranian president made no mention of the unprecedented Oct. 7 incursion by Gaza's militant Hamas group into southern Israel that sparked the latest Hamas-Israel war. Iran has long been a supporter of Hamas. \"The situation will be complicated ... if the crimes by the Zionist regime, including the killing of people and blockade of Gaza, are not stopped,\" Raisi was quoted as saying, referring to Israel. IRNA did not provide further details. Earlier, the Elysee Palace confirmed this weekend that Macron planned to talk to Raisi to urge Iran not to fuel tensions in the region or provide any operational support to Hamas. Macron intended to press the argument that bringing the violence to a rapid end is in everyone's interests, including Iran's, the presidential office said. France feels that Iran can play a positive role in the crisis by simply not getting involved in it, either with \"words that are unacceptable\" or by supporting Hamas. Over the weekend, Raisi also spoke with leaders of Arab nations of Iraq, Oman and Qatar and urged them to support Gaza's Palestinians, Iranian media said. Secretary of State Antony Blinken will return to Israel this week after completing a frantic six-country rush through Arab nations aimed at preventing the Israel-Hamas war from igniting a broader regional conflict. The U.S. State Department announced Blinken's plan to travel Monday to Israel — his second visit in five days — as America's top diplomat arrived in Cairo for talks Sunday with Egypt's president, Abdel Fattah al-Sisi. It was the last of Blinken's meetings with Arab leaders amid increasing fears that an impending Israeli ground offensive into Gaza could spark a wider war with devastating humanitarian consequences. Department spokesman Matthew Miller told reporters traveling with Blinken that the secretary was returning to Tel Aviv \"for further consultations with Israeli officials.\" Miller did not elaborate. Waving Palestinian flags, the rally also marked a major showing for the banned Islamist movement Al Adl Wa Ihssane, which supports Hamas. After Hamas's unprecedented and deadly Oct. 7 incursion into Israel, Morocco issued a statement condemning the violence. Royal Air Maroc, temporarily cancelled flights from Casablanca to Tel Aviv — a route that began in 2021. Demonstrators marched in central Rabat and threw smoke bombs and fireworks as riot police stood between them and the Parliament building and other landmarks. Hassan Ait Amar, a 52-year-old from Casablanca, carried a sign demanding Morocco's lawmakers revoke a normalization of ties with Israel. \"If they want peace, they (Israel) should respect Palestinians, international law and a two-state solution,\" he said. Israel and Morocco normalized relations as part of the 2020 Abraham Accords, a series of diplomatic agreements between Israel and four Arab countries brokered by then-President Donald Trump. Israel is home to a large community of Jews of Moroccan descent. Morocco and Israel have agreed to military cooperation and boosted trade. — Associated Press","body":{"content":[{"tagName":"div","attributes":{"className":["group"]},"data":{"__typename":"asset"},"children":[{"tagName":"p","children":["Thousands took the streets of the Moroccan capital on Sunday to rally in support of Palestinians in Gaza and denounce Israel's actions in the latest war with Gaza's militant Hamas rulers."]},{"tagName":"p","children":["Waving Palestinian flags, the rally also marked a major showing for the banned Islamist movement Al Adl Wa Ihssane, which supports Hamas. As of Saturday, 12 journalists had been killed, eight were injured and two were missing over the course of the first eight days of the Israel-Hamas war, the CPJ said in an update via its website. Of the journalists confirmed to have been killed, the CPJ said 10 were Palestinian, one was Israeli and a Beirut-based journalist was killed during a shelling attack in southern Lebanon. \"This is the The UNRWA warned that despite Israel's order to evacuate the north, many people will not be able to flee, particularly pregnant women, children, the elderly, and people with disabilities. \"UNRWA shelters in Gaza and northern Gaza are no longer safe. This is unprecedented,\" it said. \"This war should be no exception, protection of civilians and civilian infrastructure, including United Nations buildings, applies to this conflict too.\" Israel has ordered roughly 1 million residents in northern Gaza to evacuate to the south ahead of an anticipated ground offensive. Separately, the UNRWA warned that 2 million people are at risk as water runs out in Gaza and called for humanitarian supplies to be let in. It said its newly relocated base in the south is also running out of water as it takes in refugees, thousands of whom it said followed the evacuation order. UNRWA Commissioner-General Philippe Lazzarini said fuel needs to be brought in immediately to guarantee safe drinking water. \"If not, people will start dying of severe dehydration, among them young children, the elderly and women. Brent futures fell 36 cents, or 0.4%, to $90.53 per barrel and U.S. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude dropped 37 cents, or 0.4%, to $87.32 a barrel by 2215 GMT on Sunday. Both benchmarks rose nearly 6% on Friday, posting their highest daily percentage gains since April, as investors priced in the possibility of a wider Middle East conflict. Brent also recorded a weekly gain of 7.5%, its biggest such increase since February. WTI climbed 5.9% for the week. The conflict in the Middle East has had little impact on global oil and gas supplies, and Israel is not a big producer. But investors and market observers are assessing how the conflict could escalate and what it might mean for supplies from nearby countries in the world's top oil-producing region. — Reuters","body":{"__typename":"body","content":[{"__typename":"bodyContent","tagName":"image","attributes":{"id":"107275183","type":"image","creatorOverwrite":"Christopher Furlong | Getty Images News | Getty Images","headline":"GP: Middle East Instability Props Oil Price Close to All Time High 232207","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fimage.cnbcfm.com\u002Fapi\u002Fv1\u002Fimage\u002F107275183-1690003700866-gettyimages-51643968-51613615CF012_oil.jpeg?v=1697410400","caption":"Oil prices are expected to increase in the second half of 2023, according to the International Energy Forum.","copyrightHolder":"Christopher Furlong | Getty Images News | Getty Images","width":"3000","height":"2010","altText":"Oil prices are expected to increase in the second half of 2023, according to the International Energy Forum."},"data":{"__typename":"image"},"children":[]},{"__typename":"bodyContent","tagName":"div","attributes":{"className":["group"]},"data":{"__typename":"asset"},"children":[{"tagName":"p","children":["Oil prices eased in early Asia trade on Monday, reversing last Friday's rally as investors waited to see if the Israel-Hamas conflict draws in other countries, which could drive up prices further and deal a fresh blow to the global economy."]},{"tagName":"p","children":["Brent futures fell 36 cents, or 0.4%, to $90.53 per barrel and U.S. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude dropped 37 cents, or 0.4%, to $87.32 a barrel by 2215 GMT on Sunday."]},{"tagName":"p","children":["Both benchmarks rose nearly 6% on Friday, posting their highest daily percentage gains since April, as investors priced in the possibility of a wider Middle East conflict."]},{"tagName":"p","children":["Brent also recorded a weekly gain of 7.5%, its biggest such increase since February. Futures tied to the Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.05%, while S & P 500 futures and Nasdaq-100 futures gained 0.07% and 0.17%, respectively. Oil prices s piked more than 5% during Friday's session and posted their best day since April as the conflict between Israel and Hamas fueled some fears related to oil production in the region. Some on Wall Street are bracing for more volatility into year-end as yields and oil prices rise, inflation remains sticky, and conflict ensues in the Middle East, said Eric Johnston, Cantor Fitzgerald's head of equity derivatives and cross-asset. \"This Mideast situation is kind of showing that when you own equities, you are taking risks,\" he told CNBC's \" Closing Bell \" on Friday. \"As a result, you need to have good upside returns in order to justify that risk, because there are things that come out of nowhere, like this situation.\" Over the weekend , Israel's military continued urging residents to evacuate northern Gaza amid a widely anticipated ground invasion. Meanwhile, U.S. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said Sunday that the Senate would work to quickly push through a military aid package to assist Israel as it battles Hamas. Officers found the 32-year-old woman and 6-year-old boy late Saturday morning at a home in an unincorporated area of Plainfield Township, southwest of Chicago, the Will County Sheriff's Office said in a statement on social media. The statement added that the boy was pronounced dead at a hospital and the woman had multiple stab wounds and was expected to survive. An autopsy on the child showed he had also been stabbed multiple times. \"Detectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,\" the sheriff's statement said. According to the sheriff's office, the woman had called 911 to report that her landlord had attacked her with a knife, adding she then ran into a bathroom and continued to fight him off. The boy was stabbed numerous times with a knife, according to an autopsy, the sheriff's office said. The woman had more than a dozen stab wounds and remained hospitalized Sunday and was expected to survive. The Chicago office of the Council on American-Islamic Relations held a news conference later Sunday with a family member and knew their identities. It said text messages exchanged among family members showed the attacker had made disparaging remarks about Muslims. The Muslim civil liberties organization called the crime \"our worst nightmare,\" and part of a disturbing spike in hate calls and emails since the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war. — Associated Press","body":{"__typename":"body","content":[{"__typename":"bodyContent","tagName":"image","attributes":{"id":"107312412","type":"image","creatorOverwrite":"Rose Abuin | New York Daily News | Tribune News Service | Getty Images","headline":"GP: Crime Scene DO NOT CROSS sign","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fimage.cnbcfm.com\u002Fapi\u002Fv1\u002Fimage\u002F107312412-1696543104994-gettyimages-1708741612-US-NEWS-ALA-TEEN-FAMILY-SHOOTING-NY.jpeg?v=1697408194","copyrightHolder":"Rose Abuin | New York Daily News | Tribune News Service | Getty Images","width":"1200","height":"925"},"data":{"__typename":"image"},"children":[]},{"__typename":"bodyContent","tagName":"div","attributes":{"className":["group"]},"data":{"__typename":"asset"},"children":[{"tagName":"p","children":["A 71-year-old Illinois man was charged Sunday with a hate crime, accused of fatally stabbing a young boy and seriously wounding a woman because of their Islamic faith and the Israel-Hamas war, authorities said."]},{"tagName":"p","children":["Officers found the 32-year-old woman and 6-year-old boy late Saturday morning at a home in an unincorporated area of Plainfield Township, southwest of Chicago, the Will County Sheriff's Office said in a statement on social media."]},{"tagName":"p","children":["The statement added that the boy was pronounced dead at a hospital and the woman had multiple stab wounds and was expected to survive. The U.S. is also aware of 13 missing citizens and has been in contact with their families. Hamas militants stormed into Israel on Oct. 7 and murdered more than 1,400 Israelis, the vast majority of them civilians. The militants also kidnapped at least 155 people — a number that includes babies and the elderly — and are holding them hostage in Gaza. Their whereabouts are not publicly known, but their families have been urgently pressing for their release. \"The U.S. government is working around the clock to determine their whereabouts and is working with the Israeli government on every aspect of the hostage crisis, including sharing intelligence and deploying experts from across the United States government to advise the Israeli government on hostage recovery efforts,\" the statement said. Director Chris Wray said on a call with reporters Sunday that the FBI is moving quickly to mitigate the threats and that the FBI does not discount the possibility that Hamas and other groups could exploit the conflict in the Middle East to call for or plot attacks in the United States. A senior FBI official who spoke on condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the bureau said the majority of the threats that the FBI has responded to were not judged to be credible. But the official said the FBI takes them all seriously nonetheless. The official also said that agents have been encouraged to be \"aggressive\" and proactive in communicating over the last week with faith-based leaders. The official said the purpose of that outreach is not to make anyone feel targeted but rather to ask clerics and others to report to law enforcement anything that seems suspicious. Besides responding to an escalating number of threats, Wray said the FBI was also working through its legal attache office in Tel Aviv to do what it can to locate and identify Americans who remain unaccounted for after last weekend's attacks. — Associated Press","body":{"__typename":"body","content":[{"__typename":"bodyContent","tagName":"image","attributes":{"id":"107271243","type":"image","creatorOverwrite":"Jonathan Ernst | Reuters","headline":"RT: Christopher Wray: FBI Director Christopher Wray testifies before a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington - 107271243","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fimage.cnbcfm.com\u002Fapi\u002Fv1\u002Fimage\u002F107271243-16892685552023-07-12t165406z_1403545678_rc2s12ape9i8_rtrmadp_0_usa-justice-congress.jpeg?v=1697395334","caption":"FBI Director Christopher Wray testifies before a House Judiciary Committee hearing on \"oversight of the Federal Bureau of Investigation\" and alleged politicization of law enforcement, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., July 12, 2023. ","copyrightHolder":"Jonathan Ernst | Reuters","width":"3500","height":"2416","altText":"FBI Director Christopher Wray testifies before a House Judiciary Committee hearing on \"oversight of the Federal Bureau of Investigation\" and alleged politicization of law enforcement, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., July 12, 2023. The State Department set up the flights for U.S. citizens stranded in Israel, unable to leave due to the limited availability of commercial flights out of the country. \"We urge those wishing to leave to take advantage of these charters while they are available,\" the department said in a statement. Only U.S. citizens are eligible for the flights and must sign an agreement prior to departure that pledges to repay the U.S. government for the travel. The flights will leave from Israel's Ben Gurion International Airport. The department also provided details on how U.S. citizens in the Israeli city of Haifa can leave via a 10- to 12-hour ship ride to Cyprus on Monday. Those wishing to take the ship must arrive at Haifa port passenger terminal at 9 a.m. local time on Monday. The U.S. government is still negotiating how to get American citizens in Gaza out of the region. It had secured a route of safe passage via the Rafah gate border crossing from Gaza to Egypt, but Americans trying to flee reportedly still have not been let through. In the meantime, the government is encouraging Americans in Gaza to fill out a crisis intake form in case they need to be contacted on short notice. The State Department has issued a \"Do Not Travel\" advisory for Gaza and \"Reconsider Travel\" advisories for Israel and the West Bank. — Rebecca Picciotto","body":{"__typename":"body","content":[{"__typename":"bodyContent","tagName":"image","attributes":{"id":"107317337","type":"image","creatorOverwrite":"Gil Cohen-magen | AFP | Getty Images","headline":"GP: Israel-Hamas War Tel Aviv: Travellers check the departure board at Ben Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv on October 14, 2023, amid the ongoing battles between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas.","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fimage.cnbcfm.com\u002Fapi\u002Fv1\u002Fimage\u002F107317337-1697283085075-gettyimages-1723268809-AFP_33YA4ZJ.jpeg?v=1697392533","caption":"Travellers check the departure board at Ben Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv on October 14, 2023, amid the ongoing battles between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas. ","copyrightHolder":"Gil Cohen-magen | AFP | Getty Images","width":"5398","height":"3599","altText":"EDITORS NOTE: Graphic content \u002F Travellers check the departure board at Ben Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv on October 14, 2023, amid the ongoing battles between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas. The official IRNA news agency said Ebrahim Raisi and Emmanuel Macron spoke over the phone. The Iranian president made no mention of the unprecedented Oct. 7 incursion by Gaza's militant Hamas group into southern Israel that sparked the latest Hamas-Israel war. Iran has long been a supporter of Hamas. \"The situation will be complicated ... if the crimes by the Zionist regime, including the killing of people and blockade of Gaza, are not stopped,\" Raisi was quoted as saying, referring to Israel. IRNA did not provide further details. Earlier, the Elysee Palace confirmed this weekend that Macron planned to talk to Raisi to urge Iran not to fuel tensions in the region or provide any operational support to Hamas. Macron intended to press the argument that bringing the violence to a rapid end is in everyone's interests, including Iran's, the presidential office said. France feels that Iran can play a positive role in the crisis by simply not getting involved in it, either with \"words that are unacceptable\" or by supporting Hamas. Over the weekend, Raisi also spoke with leaders of Arab nations of Iraq, Oman and Qatar and urged them to support Gaza's Palestinians, Iranian media said. Ahmed Al-Mandhari said 22 hospitals with 2,000 patients in northern Gaza managed to move \"mobile patients\" to the south over the past two days but most of the patients can't be evacuated. \"It is really very risky, very dangerous if we push these hospitals to evacuate,\" he said in Cairo. Egypt has yet to reach an agreement with Israel and Hamas to reopen the Rafah border crossing to deliver medical supplies and other humanitarian aid territory to the besieged, Hamas-ruled strip. Al-Mandhari urged for the reopening \"immediately, with no delay.\" The U.N. health agency has supplies waiting in Egypt, around 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the Rafah crossing but cannot take them inside, he said. Press"]}]}]}]}},"children":[]},{"__typename":"bodyContent","tagName":"post","attributes":{"id":"107317488","type":"post","title":"Egypt's President Sisi in talks to get aid to Gaza, presidency says","datePublished":"2023-10-15T12:39:44+0000","dateLastPublished":"2023-10-15T12:39:44+0000","dateModified":"2023-10-15T12:39:44+0000","createdBy":"terri.cullen"},"data":{"__typename":"post","articleBodyText":"Egypt's president Abdel Fattah al-Sisi is in talks with international and regional partners to enable aid deliveries into Gaza and to de-escalate the fighting there, his office said on Sunday. Israeli bombardments on the Gaza side of the Rafah crossing into Egypt, the main crossing out of Gaza not controlled by Israel, have disrupted operations there. Aid from several countries has been building up in Egypt's Sinai peninsula due to a failure to reach a deal enabling its safe delivery to Gaza and enabling evacuations of some foreign passport holders through the Rafah crossing into Egypt. U.N. aid chief Martin Griffiths said on Saturday that the humanitarian situation in Gaza is \"fast becoming untenable\". The statement from Sisi's office also said Egypt rejected any plan to displace Palestinians \"to the detriment of other countries,\" and said Egypt's own security was a red line. The U.S. State Department announced Blinken's plan to travel Monday to Israel — his second visit in five days — as America's top diplomat arrived in Cairo for talks Sunday with Egypt's president, Abdel Fattah al-Sisi. It was the last of Blinken's meetings with Arab leaders amid increasing fears that an impending Israeli ground offensive into Gaza could spark a wider war with devastating humanitarian consequences. Waving Palestinian flags, the rally also marked a major showing for the banned Islamist movement Al Adl Wa Ihssane, which supports Hamas. After Hamas's unprecedented and deadly Oct. 7 incursion into Israel, Morocco issued a statement condemning the violence. Royal Air Maroc, temporarily cancelled flights from Casablanca to Tel Aviv — a route that began in 2021. Demonstrators marched in central Rabat and threw smoke bombs and fireworks as riot police stood between them and the Parliament building and other landmarks. Hassan Ait Amar, a 52-year-old from Casablanca, carried a sign demanding Morocco's lawmakers revoke a normalization of ties with Israel. \"If they want peace, they (Israel) should respect Palestinians, international law and a two-state solution,\" he said. Israel and Morocco normalized relations as part of the 2020 Abraham Accords, a series of diplomatic agreements between Israel and four Arab countries brokered by then-President Donald Trump. Israel is home to a large community of Jews of Moroccan descent. Morocco and Israel have agreed to military cooperation and boosted trade. — Associated Press","body":{"__typename":"body","content":[{"__typename":"bodyContent","tagName":"div","attributes":{"className":["group"]},"data":{"__typename":"asset"},"children":[{"tagName":"p","children":["Thousands took the streets of the Moroccan capital on Sunday to rally in support of Palestinians in Gaza and denounce Israel's actions in the latest war with Gaza's militant Hamas rulers."]},{"tagName":"p","children":["Waving Palestinian flags, the rally also marked a major showing for the banned Islamist movement Al Adl Wa Ihssane, which supports Hamas. This is unprecedented,\" it said. \"This war should be no exception, protection of civilians and civilian infrastructure, including United Nations buildings, applies to this conflict too.\" Israel has ordered roughly 1 million residents in northern Gaza to evacuate to the south ahead of an anticipated ground offensive. It said its newly relocated base in the south is also running out of water as it takes in refugees, thousands of whom it said followed the evacuation order. UNRWA Commissioner-General Philippe Lazzarini said fuel needs to be brought in immediately to guarantee safe drinking water. \"If not, people will start dying of severe dehydration, among them young children, the elderly and women.             if (window.addEventListener) window.addEventListener('load', loadScripts, false);
            else if (window.attachEvent) window.attachEvent('onload', loadScripts);

            function loadScripts() {
              (onLoadScripts || []).map(function(onLoadScript) {
                var script = document.createElement('script');

                Object.keys(onLoadScript).map(function(key) {
                  const value = onLoadScript[key];
                  if (key.includes('data-')) script.setAttribute(key, value);
                  else script[key] = value;
                });

                document.body.appendChild(script);
              });
            }
          </script></body></html>
